University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: Galfredi Chauceri Poetae Angli Incipiunt Prologi in fabulas Canterburienses .
UWhan that april wᵗith his shourez swote
Þe drought of March haþ ꝑpercyd to þᵉ rote
And bathid eủery veyn in such lycour
Of which vertu engendrid is the flour
Whan zepherus eke with his sweete breth
Enspired hath in euery holt and heth
The tendre croppes and the yong sonne
Hath in the Reyne his half cours y ronne
And smale foules makyn melody
That slepyn al the nyght with opyn ey
So prikkiþ hem nature in here coragez
Than longyn folk to gon on pilgrimagez
And palmers for to sekyn straunge strondez
To feere halwys sowt in sundry londys
And specially from eủery shirez ende
Of Englond to Cauntyrbury thei wende
The holy blisful martyr for to seke
That hem hath holpyn when thei were seeke
Befell that in that seson on a day
In southwerk at the Tabbard I lay
Redy to wendyn on my pilgrimage
To Cauntyrbury with ful deuoute corage
At nyght were comyn to that hostelry
Welnygh nyne and twenty on a company
Of sundry folk by aventure y falle
In felawshipp ; and pilgrymes were þei alle
Thei toward Cauntyrbury wold ryde
The chaumbres and the stables were wyde
And wel we weryn easid at the best
And shortly whan the sonne was to rest
So hadde I spokyn with hem euerichon
That I was of thaire felavshipp a non
And made forward erly for to ryse
To take oure weye there as I yow deuyse
But neuyr the lesse whils I haue tyme ⁊and space
Er that I forthermore in this tale pace
Me thynketh yt accordaunt to Resoun
To telle yow al the condicyoun
Of ich of hem so as yt semyth me
And which thei were and of what degree
And eke in what aray that þei were in
And at a knyght wil I furst begyn
A knyght ther was and þᵗat a wurthi man
Þat fro þe tyme þat he furst began
To ryden out ; he louyd cheualry
Trouthe and honour fredam and courtasy
Full wurthi was he in his lordis warre
And therto had he rydyn no man so farre
Als wel in cristendome as in hethnesse
And euyr was honouryd for his wurthynesse
At Alisaundre was he whan yt was wonne
And oftyn tyme he had the boorde begonne
Abouyn al nacyon in pruce
In lectow hadde he presyng and ruce
No cristen man so ofte of his degree
In garnade at the sege eke had he be
Of algezer ; and ryden in belmary
At lyeys was he and at sataly
When thei were wonne and in grete see
At many a noble arme had he be
At mortal batailles had he been fiftene
And foughtyn for oure faith in tramysene
In listes thryes and ay slough his foo
This ilke wurthi knyght hadde ben also
Sum tyme with the lord of palaty
Agayn an othir hethyn in turky
And euyr more he hadde a soueraign pryce
And though he were wurthi he was wyse
And of his port als meke as is a mayde
He neuyr yit no vilany ne saide
In al his lyfe vnto no manyr wight
He was a verray perfyte gentil knyght
But for to telle yow of his aray
His hors weryn goode but yt he was not gay
Of fustion he werid a iuppon
Al be smorchid with his haberiou
For he was late come from his viage
And went to don his pilgrimage
Uith hym þer was his sone a yong sqwier
A louere and a lusty bachiler
With lokkes crulle and thei were leid in presse
Of twenty yeer of age he was I gesse
Of his stature he was of euyn lengthe
And wundyr delyuer and of gret strengthe
And hadde been sum tyme in cheualrye
In flaundres arteys and in picardye
And born hym wel as of so lytell space
In hope to stondyn in his ladyez grace
Enbrowded was he as yt were a mede
Al ful of fressh flourys white and red
Syngyng he was or pipyng al the day
He was as fressh as is the moneth of may
Short was his gowne with slevys long ⁊and wyde
Wel couthe he sytte on hors and fayre ryde
He couth songez make and wel endyte
Iustyn ⁊and eke wel daunce purtray and wryte
So hote he louyd that by the nyghtirtale
He slept no more than doth the nyghtyngale
Curtays he was lowely and servysable
And carf before his fadir at the table
A yoman had he and seruauntz no mo
At that tyme for hym lyst ryde so
And he was clad in cote and hood of grene
A shef of pecok arwes bright and shene
Vndir his belt he bare ful thryftily
Wel couth he dresse his takil yomanly
His arwes droupid nought with fedirs lowe
And in his hand he bar a myghty bowe
A not hede had he with a brown visage
Of wodecraft wel couth he the vsage
Vppon his arme he bare a gay braser
And by his side a good swerd and a bokeler
And on that othir syde a gay dagger
Harneysid wel and sharp as poynt of sper
A cristofre on his breest of siluer shene
A horne he bar the bawdryke was of grene
A forster was he soothly as I gesse
Ther was also a Nonne a prioresse
That of her smylyng was boþᵉ symple ⁊and coy
Here grettest othe was but by seynt loy
And she was clepid ma dame Englentyne
Ful wel . she song the seruyse of dyuyne
Entunyd in hir voyce nose ful semely
And frenssh sho spak ful fayre and fetysly .
As aftyr the scole of Stratteford atte bowe
For frenssh of Paryssh was to hir vnknowe
At the mete wel taught was she with all
She leete no morsel fro hir lippes fall
Ne wet hire fingres in hire sauce depe
Weele couthe she cary a morsell and wel kepe
That no drope shul falle vppon hir breest
In courtasye was sette ful mekil hire lyst
Here ouer lyppe wiped she ouer so clene
That in here coppe ther was no forthyng sene
Of greet ; whane she had dronke her draught
Ful semly aftyr hir mete she raught
And sekirly she was of grete disport
And ful pleasaunt and amyabil of port
And peynyd here for to countyrfeet cheere
Of court ; to be estatly of manere
And to be holdyn digne of Reuerence
But for to spekyn of hir conscience
She was so charitable and so pytouse
Sho wold wepe yif that she saugh a mouse
Caught in a trappe ; yif yt were ded or bleede
Smale houndys had she þat did fede
With rostid flessh or mylk or wastil brede
But sore wept she yif one of hem were dede
Or yif men smot yt with a yerde smert
And al was conscience and tendre hert
Ful semly here wympil pynchid was
Hir nose tretys hir eyen grey as glas
Hir mouthe ful smal and therto soft and reed
But sykirly she had a fayr forhed
It was almost a spanne brod I trowe
For hardily she was not vndirgrowe
Ful fetyse was hire cloke as I was war
Of smal coral aboute hir necke she bar
A payre of bedys gaudeed al with grene
And theron heng a broche of gold ful shene
On whiche furst was wryten a crownyd .A.
And aftyr Amor vincit omniA .
AN othir Nonne with hire hadde she
That was her chapeleyn ⁊and preestez thre ;
A monk ther was a fayr for þe maystry
An outryder that louyd venery
A manly man to be an abbot hable
Ful many a deynte hors had he in stable
And when he rode men myght his brydel here
Gynglyng in a whistlyng wynde as clere
And eke as lowde as dooth the chapell belle
There as this lord was keper of the celle
The reule of seynt maure or of seynt benyt
Be cause that yt was old and sumdel streyt
This ilke monke leet olde thyngez pace
And held aftir the newe world the space
He yaf not of that text a pullid hen
That seith that hunters were not holy men
Ne that a monke that is rekkelesse
Ys likenyd to a fissh that is watirlesse
This is to sey a monk out of his cloystre
But thilk tixt he thought not wurþ an oystre
And I seyd his opynyon was good
What shuld he stody and make hym self wood
Vppon a book in cloystre alway to poure
Or swynkyn with his handys and labour
As Augustyn biddith how shal þe world be s̉eruyd
Lat augustyn haue his swynk to hym reseruyd
Therfore he was a pricasoure a right
Grehoundis he hadde as swyft as foul in flight
Of pryckyng and of huntyng for the hare
Was al his lust for no spensez wold he spare
I saugh his sleuys purfilyd at the hand
With gryce and that the fynest of a land
And for to festyn his hood vndir his chyn
He had of gold wrought a ful curyous pyn
A loue knotte in the gretter ende ther was
His hede was ballid that shon as any glas .
And eke his face as he had been anoynt
He was a lord ful fat and in goode poynt
His eyen steepe and rollyng in his hede
That stemyd as a fourneyce of a lede
His botys souple his hors in gret astate
Now certaynly he was a fayr p̉relate
He was not pale as a forpynyd gost
A fat swan louyd he best of any rost
His palfray was als brown as a bery
A frere there was a wantoıı̄un ⁊and a mery
A lymytour a ful solempne man
In al the ordres foure is non þat can
So mekil of daliaunce and fayre language
He hadde made ful many a mariage
Of yong wommen of his owne cost
Vnto his ordre he was a noble post
Ful wel belouyd and familiar was he
With frankeleyns oủeral in the cuntre
And with wurthi men in the town̄
For he hadde power of confessyon
As seid hym self more than a curat
For of his ordre he was licencyat
Ful swetly herd he confessyoun
And plesaunt was in his absolucyon
He was a visy man to gif penaun̄ce
There as he wist to haue a good pytaunce
For to pouer ordre mony for to gyue
Is signe that a man is wel shryue
For yif he gaf he durst make his avaunt
He wist wel that a man was repentaunt
For many a man so herd is of his hert
He may not wepe al though hym sore smert
Therfor in stede of wepyng and prayers
Men most gyue siluer vnto the pouere frerys
His tipet was ay farsid ful of knyfes
And pynnys for to gyfᶠ fayre wyfes
And certaynly he had a mery note
Wel couthe he synge/and play on a rote
Of yeddyngez he bar vttirly the pryce
His necke was white as is the floure delice
Therto he strong was as a champyon
He knew the taủernes wel and eủery town̄
And euerych hosteler and tapister
Bettyr than a lazar or a begger
For to swich a wurthi man as he
Accordid not as by his faculte
To haue with seek lazers acqueyntaunce
Yt is not honest yt may not avaun̄ce
For to dele with no suych pouerayle
But al with ryche and sellers of vitayle
And oủeral ther as ꝓprofyte shuld ryse
Curtayse he was and lowely of seruyse
Ther was no man nowgher so vertuous
He was the best begger of al his hous
For þough a wydew had not a sho
So plesaunt was his In principio
Yit wold he haue a ferthyng or he went
His purchace was wel better than his rent
And rage he couth right as yt were a whelp
In louedayez ther couth he mekil help
For ther he was not like a cloystrer
With a thredbare cope like a pouer scoler
But he was like a mayster or a pope
Of double wurstede was his semycope
Þat rown̄did as abell cam out of presse
Sumwhat he lispid for his wantonesse
To make his englissh sweete vppon his tonge
And in his harpyng when he had songe
His eyen twynklyd in his hede a right
As don̄ the sterrys in the frosty nyght
This wurthy lymytour was clepid hoberd
A marchaund was þ̉er wiþ a forked berd
In motle and hye on hors he satte
Vppon his hed a flaundres beuer hatte
His botys claspid fayre and fresshly
His resouns he spak ful solempnely
Sownyng alwey to the encrese of his wynnyng
He wold the feeth feefeethfee were kept for any thyng
Betwix Medilburgh and Orwell
Wel couth he in eschaunge sheldes sell
This wurthy man ful wel his wyt besette
Ther wist no wight that he was in dette
So estatly was he of his goủernaun̄ce
With his bargayns and his cheuysshaunce
For soothe he was a wurthi man with alle
But sooth to seyn I not how men hym calle
A clerk ther was of Oxenford also
That to logyk had long y go
Als lene was his hors as is a Rake
And he was not right fatte I vndirtake
But lokyd holow and therto sobyrly
Ful thredbare was his ouerest courtpy
For he hadde yit getyn hym no benefyce
Ne was so worldly for to haue office
For hym vas leuer haue at his beddis hed
Twenty goode bookys clad in blak and red
Of aristotle and of his philosophie
Than Robys ryche or fithell or gay sautrye
But al be that he was a philosophre
Yit hadde he but lytell gold in Cofre
But al that he myght of his freendys hent
On bookes and on lernyng he yt spent
And besily gan for the soules prey
Of hem that hym gaf therwith did todidto scoley
Of study took he most cure and most hede
Not a wurd spak he more than was neede
And that was seid in fourme and Reuerence
And short and quyk and ful of hye sentence
Sownyng in moral vertu was his speche
And gladly wold he lerne and gladly teche
A sergeaunt of lawe boþe war ⁊and wise
That oftyn had ben at the ꝑperuyse
Ther was also ; ful riche of excellence
Discreet he was and of gret Reuerence
Hym semyd such his wurdys were so wise
Iustyce he was ful oftyn in assise
By patent and by pleyn commyssyon
For his science and his hye Renown̄
Of fees and Robes had he manyon
So gret a purchasour was nowher non̄
Al was fee symple to hym in effecte
His purchasyng myght not be enfecte
Nowher so besy a man as he ther nas
And yit he semyd beseer than he was
In termes had he cases and domys alle
That fro the tyme of kyng willyam did falle
Therto he couthe endyte and make a thing
Ther couth no wight pinche at his wryting
And euery statute couth he pleyn by Rote
He rode but homly in a medle cote
Gird with a seynt of silk with barrys smale
Of his aray telle I no lenger tale
A frankeleyn was in his company
White was his berd as ys þe dayesy
Of his complexion he was sanguyne
Wel louyd he by the morwe a sop in wyne
To lyue in delyte was euer his wone
For he was epicurus owne sone
That hadde opynyon playn þat delyte
Was hur verray felicitee perfyte
An houshalder and þat a gret was he
Seynt Iulyan he was in his cuntre
His bred his ale was alway aftyr one
A bettyr man was nowher non
Without bake mete was neuyr in his house
Of fissh and flessh and that so plenteuouse
That the disshes were filled to the brinke
It snowyd in his hous of mete and drynke
Aftir the sundry sesons of the yeere .
So chaungid he his mete and his sopere
Ful many fatte partrike had he in muwe
And many a breme and luce had he in stue
Wo was his cook but yif his sauce were
Poynaunt and fast redy in al his gere
His table dormaunt in his halle alway
Stood redy coueryd al the long day
At sessyouns ther was he lord and syre
Ful ofte tyme had he been knyght of þe shyre
An anlas and a gisper al of sylk
Hengyd at his girdel whyte as morn mylke
And a shereue had he be and countour
Was nowher such a wurthy vauasour
An haberdassher and a carpenter
A webbe a dyer and a Tapyser
And thei were clad al in one lyuere
Of a ful solempne and gret fraternyte
Ful fressh and newe here gere pykid was
Here knyfes were chapid not with bras
But al with siluer wrought clene and wel
Here girdles and here pouchis euerydel
We semyd ich of hem a fayre burgeyse
To syttyn in a yeldhalle on a deyse
Euerich for wisdam that he can
Was shappely for to be an alderman
For catell had thei ynough and rent
And eke here wyfes wold therto wel assent
And ellis certayn were thei to blame
It is ful fayre to be clepid madame
And gone to vigilees al be foore
And haue a mantyl ryally y bore
A Cook thei hadde with þem for þe nonys
To boyle the chikenes and þe marybonys
And powdre marchaunt tart and galyngale
Wel couth he knowe a draught of londoıı̄un ale
He couth rost and sethe boyle and frye
Makyn mortrews and wel make a pye
But grete harme was yt as semyd me
That on his shyn a morymal hadde he
For blankmaunger made he at the best
A shipman was þ̉er wonyng ferre by west
For ought I wot he was of derthmouþe
He rode vppon a Rounsy as he couthe
In a gowne of faldyng to the kne
A dagger hengyng on a lace had he
About his necke vndir his arme down
The somer hote hadde made his hewe al brown
And certanly he was a good felawe
Ful many a draught of wyne had he drawe
Fro burdews ward whil that þe chapman sleepe
Of nyce conscience took he no keepe
Yif that he faught and had the hygher hand
By water he sent hem hom to euery land
But of his craftys to rekkyn wel his tydes
His streme and his daungers hym besides
His harbarwe his moone lod menage
Ther was non suych fro hul to cartage
Hardy he was and wyse to vndertake
With many a tempest had his berd been shake
He knewe alle the hauenys als thei were
Fron gotland to the gappe of fynestere
And euery cryke in bretayn and in spayne
His barge was clepid the mawdelayne
Utth vs ther was a doctoᵘur of fysike
In al this world is non hym like
To speke of fysyke and of surgerye
For he was groundid in Astronomye
He kept his pacient a ful gret deel
In hourys by his magyk naturel
Weel couthe he fortunen the ascendent
Of his ymages for his pacient
He knewe the cause of euery maledye
Were yt of hete cold moyst or drye
And where thei gendrid and of what humoᵘur
He was a verray ꝑperfyte practesour
The cause he knew and of the harme the roote
And by than the syke man hauys his boote
Ful redy had he his apotacarijs
To sendyn hym his draggez and his electuarijs
For ich of hem made othir for to wynne
Theyre frendsship̄ was not newe to begynne
Wel knewe he the olde esculapius
And discordeys and eke rusius
Old ypocras hoolly and galien
Serapyon rasis and auyseyn
Aủeroys damastyn and constantyn
Bernard gatistiden and gilbertyn
Of his dyete mesurable was he
For yt was not of no suꝑperfluyte
But gret norisshyng and digestible
His study was but litell in the bible
In sanguyne and in pers he clad was al
Lyned with taffata and with sendal
And yit he was but easy of dispence
He kept that he wan in the pestilence
For gold in phisyk is accordiall
Therfore he louyd gold in especiall
A good wyfe ther was of beside bathe
But she was sumdel def ⁊and þᵗat⁊and þᵗat þᵗat was skaþe
Of clothe makyng she hadde suych an haunt
She passid them of ypris and of gaunt
In al the parissh wyfe ne was ther non
That to the offeryng beforne hir shuld gon
And yif ther did certayn so wroth was she
That sho was out of al charyte
Here coủrechiefs ful fyn were of grounde
I durst swere thei weyed ten pounde
That on a sunday were vppon hir hed
Hir hosys were of fyn skarlet red
Ful strayte ytyed and shoōnn ful newe
Bold was hir face and fayr of hewe
She was a wurthy womman al hir lyue
Husbandys at the kirke doore had she fyue
Withoutyn othir company in youthe
But therof nedith not to speke as nouthe
And thryes had she been at Ier̄lmIerusalem
She hadde passid many a straunge strem
At Rome she hadde ben and at boloyne
In galice at seynt Iames and at coloyne
She couthe mekil of wandryng by the way
Gat tothid was she soothly for to say
Vppon an amblour soothly she satte
Wympled wel and on hir hed an hatte
Als brod as is a bokeler or a targe
A foot mantell aboute hir hippes large
And on hir feet a payre of spurrys sharpe
In felawship wel couthe laugh and karpe
Of Remedyes of loue she knewe ꝑparchaunce
For she couthe of that art the olde daunce
A good man ther was of Religion
And was a pouer ꝑparson of a toun̄
But riche he was of holy thought ⁊and werk
He was also a lernyd man a clerk
That crystis gospell truly wold teche
His parisshens deuoutly wold he preche
Benigne he was and wondyr diligent
And in aduersite ful pacient
And such he was prouyd ofte sythis
Ful loth were hym to cursyn for his tithis
But rathir wold he gyuyn out of doute
To his pouer parisshens al a boute
Of his offryng and of his substaunce
He couthe in lytill thing haue sufficeaun̄ce
Wyde was his parissh and houses fer a sundre
But he left not for Reyn ne for thondre
In sieknesse and myscheef for to visite
The ferthest in his parissh mychel and lyte

To looke on hir hym thought a mery lyfe
She was so ꝓpropir and sweete and lykerouse .
I dar wel say that yif she had ben a mouse .
And he a catte he wold haue hir hent a non
This parissh clerk this louelich absolon .
Hath in his hert such a loue longyng
That of thatnothatno wyfe took he non̄ offeryng
For curtaysly he said he wold non
The mone whan yt was nyght ful bright shon
And absolon hath his gitterne yytake
For ꝑparamoᵘurs he thought for to wake
And forth he gooth iolyf and amerous
Til he come to this carpenters hous
A lytel aftyr the cokkis hadden crowe
And dressith hym to a shot wyndowe
That was vppon the carpenters wal
He syngith in his voice gentil and smal
//Now deere lady yif your wille be
I pray yow that yee rewe on me .
Ful accordyng to his gitternyng
//The carpenter wook and herd hym syng
And spak to his wyfe and said a non
What alison herys thou not absolon
That chauntith vndir oure boure wal
And she answerd hir husbond therwith al
Yis god wot Iohan I .I . yt heere euery del
This passith forth what wil yee than but wel
From day to day this iolyf absolon
So wowith hir that hym is wo begon
He walkith al the nyght and al the day
He kembith his lokkys brode ⁊and made hym gay .
He wowith hir by menys and brokage .
And swore he wold been hir owne page .
He syngith by nyght as the nyghtygale .
He sent hir pyment meth and spised ale .
And wafres pipyng hot out of the gleede
AndAnd For she was of the toun̄ he ꝓprofrid mede .
For sum folk wil be wonne for Richesse .
And sum for strokis and sum for gentilnesse
Sum tyme to shewe his lightnes ⁊and his maystrye
He pleyeth heraud on a skaffold hye
But what auaylith hym in this caas
She louyd so hende Nicholas
That absolon may blowe the bukkis horn
He ne hadde for his labour but scorn
And thus she makid absolon hir ape
And al his ernest turnyd to a Iape
Ful sooth yt is the ꝓprouerbe yt is no lye
Men sey thus alwey the nyght slye
Makis the carterefarderecarterefardere leef to be looth
For though that absolon be wood or wroth
By cause that he fer was from hir sight
This nyght Nicholas stood in his light
¶Now bere the wel thou hend nicholas
For absolon may wayle and syng allas
//And so befel vppon a satirday
This carpenter was gon to Osnay
And hend nicholas and alison
Been accordid to this conclusyon
That nicholas shal shapyn hym a wyle
This sely Ielous husband to be guyle
And yif so be this gamyn went a right
She shuld sleepe in his armys alnyght
For this was hir desyre and his also
And right anon without wurdis mo
This nicholas no lenger wold tary
But dooth ful soft vn to his chambre cary
Bothe mete and drynk for one day or twey
And to hir husband bad hir for to sey
Yif that he asked aftyr nicholas
She shuld sey she wist not where he was
Of al the day she saugh hym not wᵗith eye
She trowid that he was in a maledye
For no cryecriercryecrier hir mayde couth hym calle
He nold answere for no thing at alle
//This passith forth al thilk satirday
That Nicholas stille in his chambre lay
And ete and slepid and did what hym list
To sunday that the sonne goth to Rest
//This sely Carpenter hath so gret mervaile
Of nicholas or what thing may hym ayle
And said I am adred by seynt Thomas
Yt stondith not a right with Nicholas
God sheeld that he be ded sodanly
This world is now ful tykill sikyrly
I saugh to day a corps born to the chirche
That now on monday last I saw hym wirche
Go vp quoth he vnto his knaue a non
Clepe at the doore and knocke with a ston
Loke how yt is and telle me boldly
This knaue goth hym vp ful sturdily
And at the chambre doore whils þᵗat he stood
He cryed and knockid as he were wood
What how what do yee mayster nicholay
How may yee sleepe al the long day
But al for nought he herd not a wurd
A hole he fand ful lowe vpon the bord
There as the catte was wont in for crepe
And at the hoole he lokid in ful deepe
And at the last he hadde of hym a sight
This nicholas sat euer gapyng vpright
As he had kiked on the newe mone
And down he goth and told his mayst̉er sone
In what aray he saugh this ilkeman
This carpenter to blissyn hym began
And said help vs seynt frideswide
A man wot lytil what shal hym betyde
This man is fallyn with his astronomy
In sum woodnesse or in sum agony
I thought ay wel how yt shuld bee
Men shuld not knowe of goddis priuetee
Ye blissid be alwey a lewde man
That nought but only his beleue can
So ferd an othir Clerk with astronomye .
He walkid in to the feeldis for to prye
Vppon the sternys what shuld befalle
Til he was in to a marl pytyy falle
He saugh not that but yit by seynt thomas
Me rewith sore of hende Nicholas
He shal be ratyd of his studeyng
Yif that I may by IhūIhesu heuyn kyng
Get me a staff that I may vndir spore
☓Whils thou Robyn heuyst vp the doore ☓
He shal out of his studeyng I gesse .
And to the chambre doore he gan hym dresse
His knave was a strong cherl for þe nonys
And by the hasp he heef yt vp at onys
And onon the floor the doore fel a non
This Nicholas sat als stille as a ston
And euyr gapid vpward vn to the ayre
The carpenter wende he were in dispayre
And hent hym by the shuldyrs myghtily
And shook hym hard and cryed dispitously
What nicholay how lookys thou adoun̄
Awake and thynk on cristes passyoun
I crouche þe fro elphis ⁊and fro wightys
Therwith the nyght spel he said anon rightes
On foure half ofof the hous aboute
And on threswold and the dore withoute
IħuIhesu crist and seynt benedight
Blisse this hous from euery wykkid wight
For the nyghtis mare with white pat̉er nost̉er
Where wonyst thou to nyght seynt pet̉er sust̉er .
//And at the last this hend nicholas
Gan to sigh sore and said allas
Shal the world be lost eft sonys now
//The carpenter answerd what says thou
What think on god as we don̄ that swinke
This nicholas answerd fecch me drynke
And aftir wil I speeke in pryuetee
Of certayn thinges that touchis me ⁊and the
I wil tel yt non othir man certayn
This carpenter goth ⁊and comyth agayn
And brought of myghty ale a large quarte
And whan that ich of hem had dronke his parte
This nicholas his doore fast hath shette
And doun̄ the carpenter by hym sette
And HeAndHe said Iohn̄ myn̄ host leef and deere
Thou shal vppon the crosse swere me heere
Thatte thou to no wight shal þis coun̄sel wrye
For yt isis cristes coun̄cel that I seye
And yif thou telle man thou art for lore
For this vengeaunce thou shalt haue þ̉erfore
That yif thou be wrye me thou shal be wood
//Nay criste for bede for his holy blood
Quoth this sely man I am no labbe
Nay though I say yt I am not leef to gabbe .
Say what thou wil I shal yt neuer telle
To no maner wight by hym that harwid helle
//Now Iohan quoth nicholas I wil not lye .
I wil telle the sooth trulye .
As I haue lokid in mone bright
That now a monday next aftyr quart̉er nyght͗e
Shal falle a rayn and þat so wild and wood
That half so gret was neuyr noe flood
This world he said in lesse than in an houre
Shal be drenklid so hidous is the shoour
Thus shal mankynde drenche ⁊and lese here lyfe .
This carpenter answerd allas my wyfe
And shal she drenche allas myn alisoun̄
For sorwe of this he fel almost a doun̄
And said is ther no Remedy in this caas
Yis forgod quoth hend Nicholas
Yif thou wil wirke by counsel and Rede
Thou may not wirke on thyn owne hede
Ful sooth saith salomon þat was ful trewe
Werke by counsel and thou shal neủer rewe
And yif thou wil wirche be good counceyl
I vndertake without mast or seil
Yit shal I saue the hir and me
Hauys thou not herd whanhowwhanhow sauyd was noe
Whan that oure lord had warnyd hym beforn̄
That al the world with watyr shuld be lorn̄
Yis quoth this carpenter ful yore a go
Hast thou not herd quoth nicholas also
The sorwe of Noe with his felashippe
Or he myght gete his wyfe vn to the shippe
Hym hadde ben leuyr I dar vndertake
At thilk tyme than alle hise wethris blake
That she hadhad hadde a shippe her selfher self alon
And therfore wost thou what is best to don̄ .
This askith haste ; and of an hasty thing
We may not preche ne make tareyng
Anon go gete vs fast in to this In
A knedyngtrowgh or ellis a kemlyn
For ich of vs but loke that thei be large
In whiche we may swymme as in a barge
And haue therin vitayl sufficient
But for on day fy on the Remanent
The watyr shal slake and gon away
About prime vppon the next day
But Robyn may not wyt of this thi knave
Ne eke thi mayde gille I may not saue
Aske not whi for though thou aske me
I wil not telle goddis pryuetee
Yt suffiseth to the but yif that þou be mad
To haue als gret grace as noe had
Thi wyf shal I wel sauyn out of doute
Go now thi way and spede here aboute
But whan thou hast for here the and me
Getyn thise knedyng tubbys thre in þˢ hous
Than shal thou hang hem in the roof hye
That no man of oure pryuete espye
And when thou thus hauys don̄ as I haue said
And hauyst oure vitail fayre in hem laid
Ank eke an axe to smyte the corde on two
Whan that the wat̉er comyth that we may go
And breke an hoole vppon the gable
In to the gardeynward oủer the stable
Þat we may frely passyn forth vppon oᵘur way
Whan that the gret shour is gon away
Than shal thou swym als mery I vndirtake
As doos the whyte duk aftir the drake
Than wil I clepe how alison how Iohan
Be mery for the flood wil passe a non̄
And thou shal sey heil mayster Nicholay
Good morwe for I se the wel yt is day
And than shal we be lord al oure lyfe
Of al the world as was noe and his wife
But one thyng I warne the ful right
Be wel avisid of allall that ilk nyght
That we been entrid in to the shippes bord
That non of vs ne speke owderowder a wurd
Ne clepe ne cry but be in his prayere
For yt is goddis owne hestys dere
Thi wyfe and thou mot hange fer atwynne .
For that betwix yow shal be no synne
No more in lokyng than shal in dede
This ordinaunce is said god the speede
To morwe at nyght whan men be on sleepe
In to oure knedyng tubbys shal we creepe
And sithen there abidyng goddis grace
Go now thi way I haue no lenger space
To make of this no lenger sermonyng
Men say thus ; send the wyse . ⁊and sey no thing
Thou art so wyse yt nedith not the to teche
Go saue oure lyfe and that I the beseche .
//This sely carpenter goth forth his way
Ful ofte he said allas and welaway
And to his wyfe he told his pryuetee
And she knew yt bettir than he
What al this quaynt craft was for to sey
But natheles she ferd as she wold dey
And said allas go forth thi way a non
Helpe vs to skape or be we ded ichon
I am thi verray trew weddid wyfe
Go deer spouse and help to saue oure lyfe
//Lo which a gret thing is affeccion
Men may dye of ymaginacyon
So deep may impression be take
This sely carpenter begynnyth to quake
Hym thynkes verraly that he may see
Noes flood come walwyng as the se
To drenchyn alison his owne deere
He wepith he waylith he makith sory cheere
He sighith with ful mony a sory swough
He goth and getith hym a knedyng trough
And aftyr a tubbe and a kemlyn
And pryuely he send hem hom to his In
And heng hem in the roof in pryuetee
His owne hand he made ladders three
To clymbyn by the Runges ⁊and the stalkes
Vnto the tubbys hangyng in the balkys .
And hem vitaylid bothe trough and tubbe
With bred and chese and good ale in a Iubbe .
Suffisyng right I nough for a day
But er that he had made al this aray
He sent his knaue and his wench also
To london vppon his erand forfor to go
And on the monday when yt drew to nyght
He shette his dore without candel light
And dressid al thyng as yt shuld be
And shortly vp thei clymbyn alle thre
Thei setyn stille wel suchsuch a furlong way
Now pater noster clum said nicholay
And clum quoth Iohan and clum qdquod alison
This carpenter said his deuocyon
And stille he sittes and biddis his prayere
Ay waytyng on the Rayn yif he yt heere
//The ded sleep for verray besinesse
Fel on this carpenter right as I gesse
About couerfu tyme or lytel more
For trauayl of his gost he gronyd sore
And eft he routyd for his hed myslay
Doun̄ of the laddir stalkys nicholay
And alisoun̄ ful soft a doun she spedde
Without wurdis mo thei go to bedde
Ther as this carpenter was wont to lye
Ther was the Reuel and the melodye
And thus lyes alison and nicholas .
In besynesse of myrthe and of solace
Til that the belle of laudes began to ryng
And frerys in theire chauncel gan syng
//This parissh clerk this amerous absolon
That is for loue alway so wo begon̄
Vppon the monday was at Osnay
With company hym to disport and play
And askid vppon a caas a cloistrere
Ful pryuely aftir Iohn̄ Carpentere
And he drough hym a party out of chirche
And said nay I saugh not here wirche
Sethyn satirday I trowe that he be went
For tymbir ther oure abbot has hym sent
For he is wont for tymbyr for to go
And dwellyn at oure graunge a day or two
Or ellis he is at his hous certayn
Where that he is I can not soothly seyn
//This absolon was ful ioyful was and light
And trowith now is tyme to wake alnyght
For sikirly I saugh hym not stiryng
About his dore sethyn day began to spryng
So mot I thryue I schal aterater cokkys crow
Ful pryuely knockyn at his wyndow
That standith ful lowe vppon his boure wal
To alyson now wil I tellyn al
My loue longyng for that I shal not mysse
That at the lest way I shal here kisse
Sum maner comfort shal I haue par fay
My mouth hath ychid al this long day
That is a signe of kissyng at the lest
Al nyght me mette that I was at a fest
Therfore I wil go sleepe an houre or twey
And al the nyght than wil I wake or pley
When that the furst cok hath crow a non
Vp ryses this ioly louer absolon
And arayed hym gay at poynt deuyse
But furst he chewith graynes ⁊and liqueryse
To smellyn swote or he had kembid his heer
Vndir his tunge a trewloue he beer
For therby he wend to be gracyous
He Romes to the carpenters hous
And stylle he stant vndir the shot wyndow
Vn to his breest yt raught yt was so low
And soft he knockid with a semly soun̄
What do yee honycombe swete alisoun .
My fayre brid my sweete cynamonee
Awake lemman myn and spek to me
Ful lityl think yee vppon my wo
That for your loue I swete ther asas I go
No wonder is though I swelt and swete
I moᵘrn̄ as dooth the lambe aftyr the tete
I wis lemmoon I haue suych longyng
That like a turtell trewe is my moᵘurnyng
I may not ete no more than a mayde
Go fro the wyndow Iak fool she sayde
As help me god yt wil not be com ba me
I loue an othir and ellis I were to blame
Wel bettyr than the by IhūIhesu absolon
Go forth thi way or I wil cast a ston
And let me sleepe a twenty deuyl way
Allas quoth absalon and welaway
ThisThis Þat trew loue was euyr so euyl besette
Than kysse me sithen yt may be no bette
For IhūIhesu loue and for the loue of me
Wil thou than go thi way therwith qdquod she .
Ye certys lemman quoth absalon
Then make the redy quoth she I com a non̄
//This absolon sette hym doun̄ vppon his knees
And said I am a lord of alle degrees
For aftir this I hope ther comys more
Lemman thi grace and swete brid thyn ore
The wyndow she vndoos ⁊and that in hast
Haue doo quoth she com of and spede þᵉe fast
Lest that oure neighboᵘurs the espy
This absolon gan wipe his mouth ful dry
Derk was the nyght as pykke or any cole
Out at the wyndow she puttys her hers hole
And absalon hym fel nouthir bettyr ne wers
But with his mouth he kissid hir nakid ers
Ful sauoᵘurly er he wer war of this
He styrt vp and thought yt was amys
For wel he wist a womman had no berd
He felt a thing al rough and long herd
And said fy allas what haue I do
Te hee quoth she and clappe hir wyndow to
And absalon goth forth a sory paas
A berd a berd seid hend Nicholas
By goddis corpus this goth fayre and wel
This sely absalon herd eủery deel
And on his lippe he gan for angir byte
And to hym self he said I shal the quyte
//Who rubbys now who fretys now his lippys
With dust wᵗith sand wᵗith straw wᵗith cloth wᵗith chippys
But absalon that sayd ful oft allas
My soule betake I to sathanas .
But were me leuyr than al þis toun̄ qᵈuod he .
Of this despyte awrokyn for to be
Allas quoth he allas that I ne had bleynt
His hot loue was cold and al a queynt
That fro that tyme that he had kist hir ers
Of paramours sette he not a kers
For he was helid of his malady
Ful ofte paramoᵘurs gan he diffy
And wept as dooth a child that is bete
A softe paas he goth hym ouyr the strete
Vn to a smyth was clepid mayster Geruays
That in his forge smythis plough harnays
He sharpith sharrys and cultres besily
This absalon knockith al easily
And seid vn to Geruays and that anon̄
What who art thou yt am I absolon
What Absalon ; what for cristis sweet tree
Whi ryse yee so rathe ey benedicite
What ayles yow sum gay gyrl god yt wot
Has brought yow thus vppon the veritot
Be seynt croyce yee wit wel what I mene
This absolon rought not a bene
Of al this play ne wurd agayn he gaf
He hadde more tough on his distaf
Then geruayse knew and seid frend so deere
That hoot cultyr in thi chymny heere
As lene yt me I haue therwith to doon
I wil bryng the yt agayn ful soon
Geruayse answerd certys were yt gold
Or in a purs noblis alle vn told
Thou shuldist yt haue as I am trew smyth
Ey for cristes fayth what wil yee do þ̉erwith
Therof quoth absolon be as be may
I shal wel telle the by to morwe day
And caught the cultyr by the cold stele
Ful soft out at the doore he gan stele
And went vnto the carpenters wal
//He callith furst and knockis therwithal
Vppon the wyndow right as he did er
This alison answerd who is ther
That knockys so I warant yt is a theef
Whi quoth he god wot my sweet leef
I am thyn absolon my derlyng
Of gold quoth he I haue the brough a ryng
My modir gaf yt me so god me saue
Ful fyne yt is and therto ful wel graue
This wil I gyf the yif that thou me gisse
//This nicholas was rysen for to pisse
And thought he wold amende al the Iape .
He shuld kysse his ers er that he escape
And vp the wyndow did he hastily
And out his hers he put pryuely
Ouer the buttok to the haunch bon
And therwith spak this absolon
Spek sweet brid I not not where thou art
This nicholas anon̄ let flye a fart
Als gret as yt had been̄ a thundir dent
And with that strok he was almost blent
And he was redy with his yren hoot
And nicholas a myddes the ers he smot
Of gos the skyn an handbrede about
The hot cultyr brent so his tout
And for yt smert he wend for to dye
As he were wood he gan for to crye
Help watir help for goddis hert
//This carpenter out of his slombyr stert
And herd one crye watyr as he were wood
And thought allas now comyth noes flood
He sette hym vp without wurdis mo
And with his axe he smot the cord a two
And doun̄ he fel he fond neuthir to selle
Bred ne ale til he cam to the telle
Vppon the floore and there in swoune he lay
Vp styrt alison and also nicholay
And cryen out and harrow in the strete
The neighbours bothe smale and grete
In ther ran to gauryn on this man
That yit in swoune lay bothe pale and wan
For with the fal he hath brustyn his arm
But stande he most vn to his awne harm
For whan he spak he was anon born̄ doun̄
With hend nicholas and alisoun
Thei told eủery man that he was wood
He was agast of Noes flood
Thurgh fantasye of his vanite
He had bought hym knedyng tubbys three
And had hem hengid in the roof aboue
And that he prayed hem for goddis loue
To syttyn in the roof pʳar company
The folk gan laugh at his fantasy
In to the roof thei looke and thei gape
And turnyd al his harme vnto a Iape
For what so this carpenter answerd
Yt was for nought no man his reson herd
With othis grete he was so born̄ down̄
That he was holdyn wood in al the toun̄
For eủery clerk anon right held with othir
Thei said the man was wood my leef brothir
That euery man gan laugh on his stryfe
Thus swyuyd was the carpenters wyfe
For al his kepyng and Ielousye
And absalon hath kissid hir nethir eye
And nicholay is skaldid in the toute
This tale is do god saue al this route

Ne at the tale I saugh no man hym greue
But yif yt were only Oswald the Reeue
Be cause he was of carpenter craft
A lytel yre in his hert laft
He gan to grucche ⁊and blamyd hym a lyte
So theek qdquod he wel couth I the quyte
With bleryng of prowd mylners eye
Yif that me lyst to speke of Ribaudrye

div.l: This white toppe wryeth myn olde yeeris
Myn hert also is moulyd as myn heer is
But I fare the frute callid as dosthe frute callidas dos an opyn ers
That ilk frute is euer lenger the wers
Til he be rotyn  right so can we not rype
We hopen ay whils that the world wil pipe
For in oure wil yt is euyr oure avayle
To haue an hore hed and a grene tayle
As hath a leek for though oᵘur myght be gon̄
Oure wil desyres foly euyr anon
Whan we may not doōn than wil we speke
Yit in oure asshis cold is fyre y reke
Foure gledis haue which þat I deuyse
Avauntyng · lyeng · angir · couetyse ·
Thise foure sparkys longyn vn to elde
Oure olde lymmys we may not wel bewelde
But wil ne shal not fayl this is sooth
And yit al weyal wey haue ik a coltissh thooth
As many a yeer as yt is passid henne
Sethyn that myn tappe of lyfe began to renne
And euer sethyn hath so the tappe y ronne
Til that almost empty is the tonne
The strem of lyfe now dropith on the thombe
And sykerly doun̄ sonkyn is the plumbe
Of wrecchidnesse that passid is ful yore
With old folk sauf dotage ther is no more
~ Whan that oure host had herd þis sermonȳng
He gan to speke as lordly as a kyng
He said what amoun̄tith al this wytte

Lastith the blisse of allaf and Custaıı̄unce

¶ For deth that takith of hygh ⁊and lowe his rent
Not passid fully a yeer as I gesse
Out of this world kyng allaf he hent
For that Custaun̄ce hath gret heuynesse
Now lat vs prey god his soule blisse
And dam Custaunce finally to say
Toward þe town̄ of Rome she goth hir way
¶ To Rome is comyn this holy creature
And fyndith hir freendis hool ⁊and sounde
Now is she skapid al hir aduenture
And whan she had hir fadir founde
Doun̄ on hir knees fallith she to groun̄de
Wepyng for tendirnesse in hert blithe
She thankith god a hundrith Mˡ1050 sithe
¶ In vertu and in almesse dede
They lyuen alle and neuer on sundir went
Til deth departe hem þis lyfe þei leede
And farith now wel my tale is at an end
Now IħuIhesu crist þat of his myght may send
Ioy aftir wo gouerne vs in his grace
And kepe vs alle þat been in this place

Explicit fabula seruientis ad
legem siue iurisperiti ⁊et iam incipti
prologus fabule Clerici Oxonie

Explicit fabula sermentis ad ⁊et
legem sine speritu et iam incipit ⁊and
prologus fabule Clerici Oxome
Syr clerk of Oxenford oure host saide
Ye ryde ale coy ⁊and stille as dooþ a mayde
Were new spousid sittyng at þe bord
This day ne herd I of yoᵘur tunge a wurd
I trow yee study about som sophisme
And Sulamon saith euery thyng hath tyme
For goddis loue as beeth of bettir chere
Yt is no tyme to study here
Telle vs sum mery tale by your fay
For what man þat is entrid in to play
Hym nedis most vn to the play assent
But preche not a freres doon̄ in lent
To make vs for oure old synnes wepe
Ne that your tale make vs for to sleepe
Telle vs mery tidynges of aduenturys
Your termes your colours and yoᵘur figures
Kepe ye in store til yee endite
Hygh stile as whan þat men to kyngys wryte
Spekyth so playn at this tyme I yow preye
That we may vndirstonde what yee say
- This wurthi clerk benygnely answerde
Host qdquod he I am vndir your yerde
Yee haue of vs alle now þe gouernaunce
And therfore wil I do yow obeisaun̄ce
Ale fewe as reson askith hardily
I wil yow telle a tale which that I
Lerd at padaw of a wurthi clerk
Prouyd by his wordis and his werk
He is now ded and naylid in a chest
I pray god gyf his soule good rest
Fraun̄cys petrak the laurirce poete
Hight this clerk whos rethoryk sweet
Enlumyned al ytaly of poetrye
As lynyan did of philosophie
Or lawe or othir artearte particuler
But deth that wil not suffre vs duelle heer
But as yt were a twııklyng of an eye
Them bothe hath slawe and alle shal we dye
Forthermore of to telle of Þis wurthi man
That taught me Þis tale as I bigan
I seye that first with his style he enditith
Er he the body of his tale writeth
A prohem in which discrnyth he
Pymonnd and of salucis the cuntre
And spekes of adpp þe hilles hye
That been þe boun̄dys of westlumbardye
And of the mount vesulus in especial
Where as the poo out of a welle smal
Taketh his furste spryngyng and his coᵘurs
By Ꝓprocesse of tyme and of hours
To Emeleward to ferare and venyce
The whiche a long thing were to deuyse
And trewly as to my Iuggement
Me thynketh yt athyng impertinent
Sauf that he wil comoyne his matere
But this is the tale which þᵗat yee shal here

There is at the right side of ytayle
Doun̄ at the rote of vesulus þe colde
A lusty playn habundaunte of vitayle
Where many a toure and toun̄ þou may bebe beholde
That foundid were in tyme of fadris olde
And many an othir delectable sight
And salus this noble cuntre hight
¶ A maarkys whilom lord of that land
As his wurthi eldres were hym before
And obeisaunt and redy to his hand
Were alle his leegis bothe lesse and more
Thus in delyt he lyueth and hath don̄ yore
Belouyd and dred by fauour and fortune
Bothe of his lordis and of his comune
¶ Therwith he was to speke as of linage
The gentlest born̄ of lumbardye
A fair ꝑpersone and strong ⁊and yong of age
And ful of honoure and of curtesye
Discrete ynogh his contre to guye
Sauf in sum thinges þat he was to blame
And walter was this yonge lordischildeschildesyonge lordisname
¶ I blame hym thus that he considred nought
In tyme comyng what myghte betyde
But on his lust p̉resent was al his thought
And for to hauke and hunte on euery side
That welnygh alle othire cures he let slide
And he ne wold and that was werst of alle
Wedde no wyfe for ought þat may bifalle
¶ Only that poynt his poeple bare so sore
Þat flokmele on a day to hym thei went
And of hem one of þe wisest þᵗat was of lore
Or ellis that þe lord wold best assente
That he shulde telle hym what þe poeple ment
Or ellis couth he shewe wel his matere
He to the markys seid as yee shal heere
¶ O noble Markys your humanitee
Assurith vs and geuyth vs hardynesse
As ofte as tyme is of necessite
That we to yow may shewe oure heuynesse
Acceptith lord now of yoᵘur gentillesse
That we with pytous hert to yow pleyn
And lete your erys my voice not disdeyn
¶ Al þough I haue not doo in this matere
More þan an othir hauys in this place
Yit for als mych as yee my lord so deere
Haue alway shewid me favoᵘur and grace
I dar the bettir haue of yow a space
Of audience to shewyn oure request
And yee my lord to do right as yow lyst
¶ For certis lord so wel vs likith yow
And al youre werk and euer haue doon̄ þᵗat we
Ne couth deuyse oure self how
That we myghte lyue in more felicite
Sauf one thyng lord yif yoᵘur wil be
That for to be a weddid man yow lyst
Than were youroueroueryour poeple in soueraigne hertishertis rest
¶ Bowith yoᵘur necke vndir that blisseful yok
Of souereignete and not of seruice
Whiche that men clepe spousayl or wedlok
And thynk lord uppon yoᵘur werkys wyse
b For þough we sleepe wake or renne or ryde
a How that oure dayes passe in sundry wyse
Ay neighith þe tyme yt wil no man abyde
¶ And þough yoᵘur grene yougþe floure as yitte
In crepith age alway als stille as ston
And deth manassheth euer age and smytte
In ich estate for there eskapith non
That also certayn as we knowe ichon
That we shal dye. asas as vncertayn we alle
Ben of that day whan deth shal on vs falle

l.hi: Nil cercius morte nil incerciꝲorum hora mort

div.l: ¶ Acceptith than of vs oure trew entent
That yit neuyr refusid your hest
And wil lord yif yee wil assent
Chese yow a wyfe in short tyme at þe lest
Borne of the gentillest and of þe mest
Of al this land and so yt oughte to seme
Honour to god and yow as yee can deme
¶ Delyuere vs out of alle þe besy drede
And taketh a wyfe for hye goddis sake
For yif yt be fel as god forbede
That thurgh your deth your lynage shulde s
And that a strong successour shulde tak
Youre heritage. O wo were vs on lyfe
Wherfore we pray yow hastily to wyfe
Here meke prayere and here meke cheere
Made the markys to haue pytee
I wil quoth he myn̄ owne poeple deere
To þat I neuer I thought erst constrayn me
I me roioysed in my libertee
That seldom tyme is foun̄dyn in mariage
Ther I was free I mot be in seruage
¶ But never the lesse I se your trew entente
And trust vppon your witte and haue don̄ ay
Wherfore of my fre wyl I wil assent
To wedde me as sone as I may
But there as yee haue ꝓprofrid to day
To chese me a wyf I wil relese
That choys ⁊and I pray yow of þat profre sese
¶ For god wot that childern̄ ofte tyme been̄
Vnlyke hir wurthi eldere hem before
Bounte comyth of god and not of the streen
I truste in good bounte and therfore
to IħuIhesu criste that god is euermore
My mariage and myn eastate and rest
I hym betake he may do as hym lyst
¶ Lat me allone in fechyng of my wyfe
That charge vppon my bak I wil endure
But I yow pray and charge yow vppon yoᵘur lyf
That whom so I take yee me ensure
To wurshippe hir while that hir lyfe may endure
In word and werk boþe here and ellis where
As she an emperous doughtyr were
¶ And forthermore this shal yee swere þat yee
Ageyn my choyce shal neuer grucche ne stryfe
For sythen I shal forgo my liberte
At your Request as euere mot I thryfe
Ther as my hert is set ther wil I wyfe
And but yee wil assentyn in this manere
I pray yow speke no more of this matere
¶ With hertly wil thei sworyn and assentyn
To al this thing þer said no wight nay
Besechyng hym of grace or that þei wentyn
That he wold vouchesauf to sette a day
Of his spousaile as sone as euer he may
For yit alwey the poeple sum dele dredde
Lest that the markys no wyfe wold wedde
¶ He grauntyd hem a day such as hym lyst
On whilk he wold be weddid sikerly
And said he did al this at here Request
And thei with humble entent buxumly
Knelyng on here knees ful Reuerently
Hym thankyn alle and thus haue an ende
Of here entent and hom agayn weende
¶ And thervppon he to his officers
Comaundith for the feste to purvey
And to his pryuee knyghtis and esquyers
Such charges hem gaf as hym list on hem ley
And thai to his comaun̄dement do obey
And euerich of hem dooth al diligence
To doon̄ vn to the feste Reuerence
¶ Not fer fro thilk paleys honourable
Where as the markys shoop his mariage
Ther stood a thorp in sight ful delectable
In which that pouer folk of þat village
Haddyn her bestis and here heritage
And of here labour took here sustenaun̄ce
Aftir that the erthe gaf hem habundaun̄ce
¶ Among thise pouer folk þ̉er duellyd a man
Which that was hold þe pouerest of hem alle
But hygh god sum tyme send can
His grace in to a litil oxes stalle
Ianicola men of that thorp hym calle
A doughtir he hadde fayre ynough in sighte
And Grysilde this yong mayden hight
¶ But for to speke of vertuous beaute
Than was she one the fayreste vnder sonne
Ful pouerly fostred was she
No likerous lust was in hir hert ronne
Wel ofter of the welle þan of the tonne
She drank and for she wolde vertu please
She knew wel labour but no thing ease
¶ But þough þis mayde tendre were of age
Yit in here brest of virginite
Ther was enclosid rype and sad curage
And in gret Reuerence and charyte
Hire old fadir toto fostred she
A fewe sheep on þe feld she spynnyng kept
She wold not be ydel vnto she slept
¶ And when she homward came she wold bryng
Wurtys and othir herbis tymes oft
Vnto hir old fadres sustenyng
And ay tendirly she kept his lyfe on loft
With honest kepyng benyngly and soft
And with al maner obeisaun̄ce and ofandof diligence
That child may doo to faders Reủerence
¶ Vppon Grisilde that pouer creature
Ful ofte tymes þˢisþˢis markes set his eye
As he on huntyng rode par auenture
And whan yt befal he myght hir espye
He mot with wanton lokyng of folye
His eyen cast on hir but in sad wyse
Vppon hir chere he wold hym ofte aduyse
¶ Couetyng in his hert hir wommanhede
And eke hir vertues passyng euery wight
Of so yong age als wel in chere as dede
For thogh poeple hath non insight
In vertu he considred right
Hir bounte and that dispose he wold
To wedde hir only yif he wedden shuld
¶ The day of weddyng come but no wight can
Telle what womman yt shuld be
For which thing wondir many a man
And said whan thei were in pryuete
Wil not oure lord leue his vanyte
Wil he not wedde allas allas þe while
Whi wil he hym self and vs beguyle
¶ But neuer the lesse the markys hath do make
Of gemmys set in gold and in asure
Brochis and Rynges for Grisildes sake
And of the clothing took meusure
Of a mayden like to hir stature
And eek of othir ournamentis alle
That vnto such aweddyng shal falle
¶ The tyme of vnderne þe same day
Approchith þat this weddyng shuld be
And al the place put was in array
Bothe halle and chambris ech in his degree
Houseis of offices stuffid with plentee
Ther mayst thou see of daynteuous vitayl
That may be founde als ferre as lastis ytail
¶ This royal markys richely arrayed
With lordis and ladies in his company
The whith that to the fest were prayed
And of his retenu the bachillery
With many soun̄ of diverse melody
Vnto the village of the which I told
In this array the right way thei hold
¶ Grisild of this god wot wel Innocent
That for hir shapyn was al this array
To fecche watir at a welle is went
And comyth ageyn as sone as eủer she may
For wel she hadde herd seyd þat ilk day
ThatÞᵉThatÞᵉ markys sholde wedde and yif she myght
She wolde fayn han seyn som of þat sighte
¶ She thoght she wold with othir maydenys sta
That been my felawys and in oure dore see
The markis wyfe and þerfore wil I fond
To don̄ at home als sone as yt may bee
The laboure the which þat longeth vn to me
And than I may at leyser hir behold
Yif she this way vnto the castel hold
¶ And als she wold ouer hir thresshold gon
The markis cam and gan hir for to calle
And she sette doun̄ hir watir pot a non
Byside the thresshold of the oxen stalle
And doun̄ vppon hir knees she gan to falle
And with þat contynaun̄ce knelid stille
Til she had herd what was the lordis wille
¶ This thoghtful markis spak vnto þe mayde
Ful sobirly and said in this manere
Where is your fadir o grisild he saide
And she with Reuerence and humble cheere
Answerd lord he is al redy heere
And in she gooth without legger lette
And to the markis she hir fadir fette.
¶ He by the hand took this old man
And thus seid whan he had hym o syde
Ianicula I neuer may ne can
Lenger the pleasaun̄ce of myn hert hyde
Yif that thou vouchesauf what so betyde
Thi doughtir wil I take er that I weende
As to my wyfe to oure lyfes eende
¶ Thou louys me I wot yt wel certayn
And art my faithful legeman ybore
And al that likes me I dar wel sayn
Yt likith the and especially therfore
Telle me that poynt as I haue said before
Yif that thou wil vn to my purpos drawe
To take me as for thi sone in lawe
¶ This subitan caas this man astonyed so
Þat red he wex abasshid al ⁊and quakyng
He stood; vnnethis said he wurdis mo
But only this; lord qdquod he my willyng
Is as yee wil; ne ageyn your likyng
I wil no thyng do; yee be my lord so deere
Aght as yow list gouernyth this matere
¶ Yet wil I do this quoth þe markis softly
That in a chambre I and thou and she
Haue a collacyon and wotyst thou whi
For I wil aske if yit hir wille be
To be my wyfe and rule hir aftir me
And al this shal be doon̄ in thi presence
I wil not speke out of thyn̄ audience
¶ And in the chambir while þei were aboute
Here trety which yee shul aftir heere
The poeple cam vn to the hous withoute
And wondird hem in how honest manere
And daynteffully she kept hir fadir deere
But uttirly Grysild wondir myght
For neuer eþft saugh she suych a sight
¶ No wondir is yif she were astoonyd
To see so gret a gest come in that place
She neuer was to such gestis wonyd
For which she lokid with a ful pale face
But forth this mater shortly for to chace
Thise been the wurdes that this markis said
To this benyngne and stedfast mayd
¶ Grisild he said yee wil wel vndirstand
Yt likith to your fadir and to me
That I yow wedde and eke yt may so stand
As I suppose that yee wil þat yt so bee
But this demaun̄de aske I furst qdquod he
That sithen yt shal be don in hasty wyse
Wil yee assent or ellis yow aduyse
¶ I say this be yee redy with good herte
To al my lust and I frely may
As yow best thenke; doo ye laugh or smerte
And neuer to grucche nyght ne day
And eke whan I sey yee; sey yee not nay.
Nouthir by wurd ne by froward contynnānce
Swere mymy this; and I sure yow alliaun̄ce
¶ Wrondryng vppon this wurd quakyg͗e for drede
She said lord vndigne and vnwurthi
Am I to thilk honour that yee me beede
But as yee wil your self so wil I
And here I swere that neuer willingly
In werk ne thoght I nyl yow disobeye
For to be to be dede þough me were loth to deye
¶ This is ynough Gresild deere qdquod he
And forth he goth with a noble cheere
Out at the doore and aftyr cam she
And to the poeple he said on this manere
This is my wyfe qdquod he that stondith here
Honourith hir and loueth hir I yow pray
Who so louyth me ther is no more to say
¶ And for that no thyng of hir old gere
She shuld bryng onon to his hous he bad
That wommen shuld dispoyle hir there
Of whiche thise ladies were not right glad
To handle hir clothis wherin she was clad
But neuer the lesse þis mayden bright of hewe
From foot to hed thei clothid al newe
¶ Hir her haue thei kempt þat lay vntressid
Ful rudely; and with fyngris smale
A corone on hir hed thei haue dressid
And sette hir ful of nouchis gret ⁊and smale
Of hir array what shuld I make a tale
Vnnethe þe poeple hir knew for hir fayrnesse
Whan she transmutyd was in such richesse
¶ This markis hath hir spousid with a ryng
Brought for the same cause and þan hir sette
Vppon an hors white and wel amblyng
And to his palace er he lenger lette
With ioyful poeple þat hir ladde and mette
Conueyhid hir and thus the day thei spende
In Reuel til the sonne gan destende
¶ And soothly forth mymy tale for to chase
I sey that to this newe marchiesse
God hath hir such fauour sent of his grace
That yt ne semyd not be liklynesse
That she was born̄ and fed in rudenesse
As in aa cote or in an oxes stalle
But norisshid in an Emperours halle
¶ To euery wight waxen is she so deere
And wurshipful that folk þer she was born̄
And fro hir burthe knewe hir yeer by yeere
Vnnethe trowid thai but þei durst haue sworn̄
That to Ianicla of which I spak beforn̄
She doughtyr ne were for as by coniecture
Hem thought she was an othir creature
¶ For though þat euer vertuous was she
She was encresid in such excellence
Of maners that god set in hir bounte
And so discreet and fayre of eloquence
So benigne and digne of Reuerence
And couthe so the poeplis hertis enbrace
That eủery man hir louyth þᵗat lokith in hir face
¶ Not only of saluces in the toun̄
Puplisshid was þe boun̄te of hir name
But eke bysede in many a region
Yif one seid wel an othir seid the same
So spradde of hir boun̄te the name
That men and wommen als wel yong as olde
Gon̄ to Salucez hir for to beholde
¶ Thus lowely Walter nay but Royally
Is weddid with fortune and honeste
In good pees lyueth he ful easily
At home and outward grace ynoug had he
And for he saugh þat undir lowe degree
Was oftyn vertu hydde; the poeple hym heeld
A prudent man and that is seen ful seeld
¶ Not only Grisild thurgh hire wytte
Couth al the feet of wifly holynesse
But eke whan the caas requyrid yt
The comune ꝓprofyte she couth redresse
That ther ne was discord RancᵘurRancᵘur ne heuynesse
In al that lond that she ne couth apayse
And wisely bryng hem at rest and atat ayse.
¶ Þough that hir husbond were absent or non̄
Yif gentil men or othir of hir cuntre
Were wrothe she wold bryng hem at one
So wyse and yeepe wurdis hadde she
And Iuggementis of gret equytee
That chiechie from heuyn sent was as men wende
the poeple to saue and euery wrong to amende
¶ Not longe timetime aftir; this Grisild
Was weddid a doughtir had she bore
Þough hir were leuer haue had a knaf child.
Glad was the markis and his folk therfore
For þough a mayde child come al before
She may to a knaf child aftiraftir attayne
By likehed sithen she is not barayne
¶ Ther fel as yt befallis tymes mo
Whan this child had soukid but a throwe
This markys in his hert longith so
To tempte his wyfe hir sadnesse for to knowe
That he ne myght out of his hert throwe
This mervaillous desir his wil for to assay
Neuer the lesse god wot he thoyght hir to afray
¶ He had hir assayed ynough before
And fond hir euyr good what nedis yt
Hir to tempte; and alway more and more
Yit sum men prayse yt for a subtil wyt
But as for me y sey that euyl ys yt
To assay a wyfe whan yt is no nede
And to put hir in anguissh and in drede
¶ For which this markis wroght in þis man
He cam on nyght allone ther as she lay
With sterne face and with trouble cheere
And said thus Grisild quoth he that day
That I yow took out of pouer array
And put yow in the eastate of hye noblesse
Yee haue not yit forgetyn as I gesse
¶ I sey Grisild this present dignitee
In whiche I haue put yow as I trowe
Makis yow not for getful to bee
That y yow took in pouer eastate ful lowe
For any welthe yee mot yoᵘur self knowe
Take heed of euery wurd þat I say
Ther is no wight that herith but we tway
¶ Yee wot your self wel how yee come here
Into this hous yt is not long a go
Ynough to me yee bothe leef and dere
Vnto my gentles yee be no thing so
I say to hem yt is gret shame and wo
For to be subiectis and in seruage
To the that art born̄ of smal lynage
¶ And namely sithen þi doughtir was bore
Thise wurdis haue thei spoke doutles
But I desire as I haue don̄ her before
To lyue with hem in rest and pees
I may not in this caas be recheles
I mot doon with thi doughtir for the best
Not as I wold but as my gentlis lyst
¶ And yit god wot yt is ful loth to me
But neuer the lesse without yoᵘur watyng
I wil nat do this; this is my wil quoth he
That yee to me assent as in this thyng
Shewe now your pacience as in wirkyng
That yee me hight and swore in yoᵘur village
That day that made was oure mariage
¶ Whan she had herd al this no thing amoenyd
Nouthir in wurd ne cheere ne contynaun̄ce
For as yt semyd she was not agreuyd
She said lord al liggith in yoᵘur pleasaun̄ce
My child and I with hertily obeisaun̄ce
Been youre; al may yee saue or spille
Your owen thing; werkith aftir yoᵘur wille
¶ Ther may not as god my soule saue
Likyn to yow. that may displease me
But I desire no thing to haue
Ne drede to lese but only the
This wil is in myn hert and ay shal be
No lengthe of tyme or deth may yt deface
nemaynemay chaunge my curage to any othir place
¶ Glad was the markis for hir answeryng
But yit he feynyd as yt were not so
Al drery was his cheere and lokyng
Whan that he shuld out of þe chambir go
Sone aftir this a furlong way or two
He playnly hath told al his entent

¶ In maner of a sergeaunt was this pⁱriue man
The which þat faythful ofte he foun̄dyn had

To his entent als wel as any man
Doon̄ execucyon of thinges badde

¶ Madame he said yee mot forgif yt me
To do thing which I am constreynyd
Yee been so wyse that wel knowe yee
That lordis hestis may not be feynyd

¶ But men mot nedys vnto here lust obeye
And so wil I there is no more to seye
¶ The child I am comaun̄did for to take
And spak no more but vp the child he hent
Dispotously and gan a cheere make
As though he wold haue slayn yt or he went
Grisid mot al suffre and al consent
And as a lambe she sittith meke and stille
And leet the cruel sergeaunt haue al his wille
¶ Suspecyous was the diffame of this man
Suspecte his face suspecte his wurd also
Suspecte the tyme in which he this began

She wend he wold haue slayn hir right tho
But neuyr the lesse she wepid not ne sykid

¶ But at the last to spekyn she began
And mekely to the sergeaunt che;absent:che prayed

And in hir arme this lytel child she leyde

And lullid yt and aftir gan yt kisse
¶ And thus she seid in hir benygne voyce
Fare wel my child I shal þe neuyr see
But sithen I haue the markyd with the croyce
Of thilk fadir blissid he mot bee
That for vs dyed vppon a crosse of tree
Thy soule litil child I hym betake
For this nyght dye thou shalt for my sake
¶ I trowe to an othir in this caas
Yt hadde ben ruthe this thing to see
Wel myght a moder haue cryed allas
But neuer the lesse so sad and stedfast was she
That she endurid al aduersytee
And to the sergeaunt mekely she saide
Haue here agayn my litil yong mayde
¶ And goth now and doth my lordis hest
But one thing wold I pray yow of yoᵘur grace
That but yif my lord forbad yow at þe lest
Buryeth this litil body in sum place

But he wold no wurd to that purpose say
But took the child and went vppon his way
¶ That sergeaunt come vnto his lord agayn
And of Grisild wurd and cheere
From poynt to poynt to told shortly ⁊and playn
And hym presentid with his doughtir deere
Sum what this lord had ruthe on his manere
But neuer the lesse his purpos held he stille

¶ And bad this sergeaunt that pryuely
He shuld this child heelyn and wrappe

And cary yt in a cofre or in a lappe
But on peyn of his hed of to suappe

¶ But at boleyn to his suster deere
That ilk tyme of pauik was Countesse
He shuld yt take and shewe hir this mattere
Besekyng hir to do hir besinesse
This child to fostre in al gentilnesse
And whos child yt was he bad hir hide

¶ The sergeaunt goth and hath fulfilled þis þing
But to this markis now retourne we
For now goth he ful of ymagynyng

¶ As glad as humble as besy in seruice
And eke in loue as she was wont to be
For she was to hym in al maner wyse
Ne of hir doughtir one wurd spak she
Ne accident for non aduersitee
Was seen̄ in hir ne neuer his doughtir name

¶ In this eastate passid been foure yeere
Er she with child was; but as god wold

Þe which ful gracious was to behold
And whan that folk to his fadir told
Nat only he but al his cuntree mery

¶ Whan yt was two yeer old ⁊and from þe breest

¶ Wyfe quoth þis marke yee haue herd this

And namely sithen my sone born̄ is

¶ Now sey thei thus when walt is a gon
Þan shal þe blood of Ianicola vs on̄ spreede

Such wurdis saith my poeple yt is to drede
Wel aught I of such wurd take heede
For certanly I drede such sentence

¶ I wold lyue in pees yif þat I myght
Wherfore I am disposid vttirly
As I his sister seruyd by nyght

This warne I yow for yee not subitanly

¶ I haue quoth she said thus and euer shal
I wil no thing do ne no thing clayme
But as yow lust not greuyth yt me at al
Þough þat my doughtir and my sone be slayn

I haue no part of tho children tweyne
But furst seeknesse and aftir wo and peyne

Whan I furst come to yow right so qdquod she

She louyd hir childern̄ best in euery wyse
But now of wommen wold I aske fayn
Yif thise assayes myght not suffise

þat she to hym was chaun̄gid of curage
But neuer couth he fynd variaun̄ce
She was euer one in hert and inin visage
And euer the ferther þat she wax in age

¶ For which yt semyth þus þat of hem two
Ther was but one wil; for as Walter list
That same lust was hir plesaun̄ce also
And god be thankid al fel for the best

¶ He of his cruel purpos wil not stynt

Wend ful wel yt had been̄ right so

¶ Abydyng euer his lust and his pleasaun̄ce
To whom she was yonyn hert and al
As to hir wordly verray sufficeaun̄ce
But shortly of this history telle I shal
This markis wretyn hath in especial

But on thyng he hym prayd witterly

¶ But sey that the mayde shuld weddid be
Vnto markys of Saluce a non̄
And as the erl was prayd so did he
For at the day set he on his way is gon̄
Toward Saluce and lordis many on
In ryche array this mayde for to guyde

¶ Arrayed was toward this mariage
This fressh mayde ful of gemmys clere
Hir brothir that by yeer was of age
Arrayed eke ful fressh on his manere

¶ Among aftir this wikkid vsage

Ful boystustly hath seid hir his sentence
¶ Certes Grisild I had ynough pleasaun̄ce
To haue yow to my wyfe for yoᵘur goodnesse

Not for your lyenage ne for yoᵘur richesse

That in gret lordship as I wil aduyse
Ther is gret soueraignte in sundry wyse
¶ I may nat do as euery ploughman may
My poeple me constreynyth for to take
An othir wyf and cryen day be day

Consenteth yt I vndertake
And trewly thus mych I dar wel say
My newe wyfe I dar welI dar wel is comyng on þᵉ way

Take yt agayn I graunt yt of my grace
Retournyth to yoᵘur fadirs hous qdquod he
No man may haue alway prosperyte

The strok of fortune orandorand of aduenture
¶ And she ageyn answerd in pacience
My lord quoth she I wot and wist alway
How that betwix youre magnificence
And my pouerte no man can ne may
Make comparison yt is no nay
I held me neuer digne in no manere
To be your wyfe ne your chamberere
¶ And this house ther yee me lady made
The hye god take I for my wittenesse
And as wistly he my soule glade
I neuer held me lady ne maystresse
But humble seruaunt to yoᵘur wurthynesse
And euyr shal while þᵗat my lyfe may endure
Abouen euery wordly creature
¶ That yee so long of yoᵘur benignyte

Where I was not wurthi to bee
That thanke I god and yow to whom I preye
Foryeeld yt yow ther is no more to sey
Vnto my fadir gladly wil I weende
And with hym therethere dwelle to my lyfis eende
¶ There I was fostred of child smal
Til I be ded ther my lyf wil I lede
A widowe clene in hert body and al
For sithen I gaf to yow my madenhede
I am yoᵘur trewe wyfe yt is no drede.
God sheeld such a lordis wyfe shuld take
An othir man to husband or to make
¶ And of your new wyfe god of his grase
so graunt yow welthe and prosperite
For I wil gladly yeld hir my place
In whiche I was blisseful wont to be
For sithen yt likes yow my lord so free
That whilom were al my hertis rest

¶ But therther as yee me profre such dowayre

¶ But sooth yt is seid algate I fynd yt trew
For in effecte yt prouyd is in me

¶ My fourthe husband was a Reuelour

Ne of non othir wommen . neuer the mo

IN the olde dayes of the kyng arthure
Of which þat bretonis spak gret honure
Al was this land fulfillid of fayrye
The eluyssh queene with hir ioly compaignye
Daunsid ful oft in many a grene mede
This was the old opinion as I rede
I speke of many a hundrith yeer agoo
But now knowith no man elfys mo
For now thurgh the gret prayers
Of goddis mynystris and his officers
That serchen euery land and euery strem
As thikke as motys in the sunne bem
Blissynge hallys chambrys and bourys
Cytes burghwis castels and tours
Thorpys bernes shipnys dayeryes
This makith þat ther be no fayeryes .
For there as was wont to walke an elfe
Ther walkith now þe lymytoᵘur of god hym selfe
And says his mateynys and his holy thyngys
In vndyrmelys and in morwenyngys
As he goth in his lymytacyon
Wommen may go now saufly vp and doun̄
In euery bussh or in euery tre
Ther is non othir Incubus but he
And he wil do no dishonoure
¶ And so befel that this kyng Arthure
Had in his hous a lusty Bachillere
That on a day come rydyng fro a Ryuere
And happid allone as she was born̄
He saugh a mayden walkyng hym beforn
Of whiche mayde a non maugre hire hed
By verray force he raft hir maydenhed
For which oppression was such clamour
And such pursute vnto kyng arthur
That dampnyd was þis knyght for to be ded
By cours of lawe and sholde haue lost his hed
Par aduenture such was the statute tho
But that the queene and othir ladyes mo
So longe prayed the kyng of grace
Til he had his lyfe hym grauntid in þat place
And gaf hym to the queene al at hir wille
To chese wheithre she wold hym saue or spille
The queen thankyd þe kyng with al hir myght
And after this thus spak she to the knyght
Whan that she saw hir tyme on a day
¶ Thou stondist yit qdquod she in such aray
That of thi lyfe hauys thou no seurte
I graunt the lyfe yif thou can telle me
What thing yt is that wommen most desyren
Bewar and kepe thi necke bon̄ from yren
And yif thou canst not telle yt me a non
Yit wil I gyf the leue for to gon
Twelf moneth and a day to seekee and leere
An answer sufficiaunt of this mateere
And seurte I wil haue or þat thou pace
Thi body for to yeldyn in this place
Wo was the knyght and sorwefully he sighith
But he may not do al as hym likith
And than at the last he chese for to wende
And come ageyn right at þe yeeris ende
With such answer as god wil hym purvey
And takys his leeue and went forth his wey
He sekith euery hous and euery place
Where as he hopith for to fynde grace
To lerne what thing wommen louyn most
But he ne couth arryuyn in no coost
Where as he myght fynde in this matere
Two creatures accordyng in feere
Sum seidyn wommen louyn best richesse
Sum seidyn honour sum seidyn Iolylynesse
Sum seide riche array sum seide lust in bedde
And oftyn tyme to vidow and to wedde
Som seide þat oure hert is most easid
Whan that we be ylaterid and pleasid
He goth ful nygh þe sooth I nyl not lye
A man shal please his wyfe with flaterye
And with attendaunce and with besynesse
We been releuyd bothe more and lesse
And som men sey how that we louyn best
For to be free and do right as vs lyst
And that no man repreue vs of oure vice
But say that we be wyse and no thing nyce
For truly ther is non of vs alle

Ful many cause leef sire Sommonour .
Said this feend but al thing hath tyme
The day is short but yt is passid pryme
And yit wan I no thing this day
I wil attend to wynnyng yif that I may
And not entende oure wits to declare
For brothir myne thy wyttis been al to bare
To vndirstand al þough I telle yt the
But for thou askid whi laboure we
For sum tyme we been goddis Instrumentys
And menys to doon̄ his comaundementys
Whan that hym lust vppon his creaturys
In dyuerse art and in dyuerse figurys
Withoutyn hym we haue no myght certeyn
Yif that hym lust to stande therageyn
And sum tyme at oure prayer haue we leue
Only the body and not the soule to greue
Wittenesse of Iob whom we did gret wo
And sum tyme haue we myght of boþe two
That is to sey of soule and of body eke .
And sum tyme been we suffrid for to seke
Vppon a man and doon his soule vnrest
And not his body and al is for the best
Whan he withstandis oure temptacyoun
Yt is cause of his saluacyoun
Al þough yt was not oure entent
He shuld be sauyd ; but þᵗat we wold hym hent
And sum tyme be we seruauntys vnto man
As to the archbisshop̄ seynt dıı̄unstan
And to the apostlis seruaunt eke was I
¶ Yit telle me quoth this Sommonoᵘur faithfully
Make yee yow bodyes thus alway
Of elementys the feend answerd nay
Sum tyme we feyne and sum tyme we ryse
With ded bodies in sundry wise
And speke als renably fayre and wel
As the phitonissa did samuel
And yit wil sum say yt was not he
I gif no force of your diuinytee
But of one thing warne I þe I wil not iape
Thou wilt algate wyt how we be shape
Thou shalt lere aftirward my brothir dere
Som therof the nedis not of me to lere
For thou shalt by thyne owne experience
In a chayer kun rede . of this sentence
Bettyr than virgil whils þat he was on lyue
Or dauid also now lat vs ryde bylyue
For I wil hold company with the
Til yt be so that thou forsake me
¶ Nay quoth this Sommonoᵘur this shal not betyde
I am a yoman that knowyn is ful wyde
And trouthe wil I hold as in this caas
For þough thou were the deuyl Sathanas
My trouthe wold I holde to the my brothir
As I am sworn̄ and ich of vs to othir
For to be trewe brothir as in this case
And bothe we gon al about oure purchase
Take thou thi part þat men wil the gyue
And I shal myne and thus shal we boþe lyue
And yif that any of vs haue more þan othir
Lat hym be trew and part with his brothir
¶ I graunt quoth the deuyl by my fay
And with that wurd thei ride forth þ̉er way
And right at the entryng of a toun̄ hende
To which this Sommonoᵘur shoop hym to wende
He saw a cart that chargid was with hay
Which that the carter drof forth in þe way
Deep was the way for þe which þe cart stood
The carter smot and cryed as he were wood
Hayte brok hayt skot . what spare yee for þᵉ stonys
Þe deuyl quoth hehe fecche yow . boþe body and bonys .
Als ferfort as euer were yee folid
So mich wo as I haue with yow tholid
The deuyl haue al bothe hors cart and hay
¶ This Sommonoᵘur said here shal we haue a play
And neer the deuyl he drough as nough ne were
Ful pryuely he ronnyd in his ere
Herkyn my brothir herke by my fay
Herdist thou not how þe carter gan say
Hent yt a non for he hath gouyn yt the
Bothe hay and carte and his caples three .
¶ Nay quoth the deuyl god wot neuer a deel
Yt is not his entent trust thou me weel
Aske hym thou thi self yif thou trowist not me
Or ellis stande stille a while and þou shalt see .
¶ The carter thakkis his hors vppon thi croupe .
And thei began to drawe and to stoupe .
Hayt now he said iħuIhesu crist yow blisse
And alle his handwerkis bothe more ⁊and lesse
That was wel twight myne own lyard boy
I pray to god saue the and seynt loy
Now is my cart out of the slough parde
¶ Lo ; brothir quoth the feend what told I the
Here may thou see myn owne deere brothir
That he spekis one thing and thinkis an othir
Lat vs go forth about oure viage
For here wynne no thing vppon cariage
Whan that þei comyn sum what out of þe toun̄
This Sommonoᵘur to his brothir gan to roun̄
¶ Brothir quoth he here wonys an old rebekke
That had als leef almost to lese hir necke
As for to gyf a peny of hir good
I wil haue xii . d though þat she be wood
Or I wil sommoun̄ hir vnto oure office
And yit of hir god wot know I no vice .
But for thou canst not as in this cuntree
Wynne thi cost take here exsample by me
¶ This Sommonoᵘur clappid at the widewis gate .
Come out quoth he thou verray old trate
I trowe thou hauyst som frere or preest with the
Who clepith seid this wyfe benedicite
God saue yow sir what is yoᵘur sweet wille
¶ I haue quoth he of somoıı̄uns a bille
Vppon peyn of cursyng loke þat thou be
To morwe before the archdiaconys kne
To answer to the court of certayns thinges
¶ Now lord qdquod she ihūIhesu criste kyng of kynges
So wistly me help as I ne may
I haue been seeke and þat ful many a day
I may not go so fer quoth she ne ryde
But yif I be ded so prykkith it vndir my side
May I not aske a bille sir Sommonour
And answer ther by my proctour
To swich thynges as men wil aspose me
¶ Yis quoth the Sommonoᵘur pay anon lat see
xii . d . to me and I shal the acquyte
I shal no profyte haue therby but lyte
My mayster hath the profyte and not I
Com of and lat me ryde hens hastily
Gif me xii . d I may no lenger tary
¶ xii . d . quoth she now lady seynt mary
Now wistly help me god out of care and synne .
This wyde world þough that I shuld wynne
Ne haue I not xii . d . within my houshald
Yee knowe wel that I am bothe pouer ⁊and old
Kithe your almesse on me pouer wrecche
¶ Nay than quoth he the feend away me fecche
Yif I the excuse þough þou shuld be spilt
¶ Allas quoth she god wot I haue no gilt
Pay me quoth he or by sweet saynt anne
As I wil bere away thi newe panne
For dette whiche thou owis me of old
Whan thou made thi husbond cukkewold
That I paid to haue thi correccyoun̄
¶ Thou lixt quoth she by my saluacyoun̄
Ne was I neuer or now widue or wyfe
Somoned to your court in al my lyfe
Ne neuyr was I but of my body trewe
Vnto the deuyl blak and rough of hewe
Gyf I thi body and my panne also
And whan the deuyl herd hir cursyn so
Vppon hir knees sayng on this manere
Now malkyn quoth he myne owne modir deere
Ys this youre wille in ernest þat yee say
Ye . quoth she the deuyl fecche hym away
Panne and al but yif he wil hym repent
¶ Nay olde stotte that is not myn̄ entent
Quoth this Sommomoᵘur for to repente me
For any thing that I haue had of the
I wold I hadde thi smok and euery cloth
Now brothir quoth the deuyl be not wroth
Thi body and this panne been myne be right
Thou shalt with me to helle this same nyght
Where thou shalt knowe of oure pryuetee
More than a mayster of dyuynytee
And with this wurd this foul feend hym hent
Body and soule and panne to the deuyl went
Where as that Sommonoᵘur hath his heritage
And god that made aftir his ymage
Mankynde ; saue and keepe vs alle and some
And leue thise Sommonoᵘurs good men to become .
Lordyngis I couth telle yow quoth þis frere
Had I had layser for this Sommonoᵘur here
Aftir the text of paule and Ioħan
And of oure othir doctours manyan
Such peynes that oure hertis myght agryse
Alþough yt be so oure tungis may not deuyse .
Þough that I myght ; in a mᵇ yeer telle
The payne of thilk cursid court of helle
But for to keepe vs from thilk cursid place
Wakith and prayeth ihuIhesu of his grace
To kepe vs from thilk temptatoᵘur Sathanas
Herkenyth this wurd beth war as in þis caas
The lyoun̄ sittyth in his awayte alway
To sle the Innocente yif þat he may
Dispose ay youre hertis to withstand
The feend that yow wold make thral ⁊and bond
He may not tempte yow ouer your myght
For crist wil be your champioıı̄un and knyght
And pray we that þise Sommonoᵘurs hem repent
Of her mysdedid er that þe feend hem hent
