This Sommonoᵘur in his stirop vpstod
Vppon this frere his hert was so wood
That lyke an aspyn̄ leef he quook for Ire
Lordynges qdquod he but one thing I desire
I beseche yow that of your courtasye
Sithen yee haue herd this fals frere lye
As suffreth me þat I may a tale telle
This frere bostith þat he knowith helle
And god wot yt is but litil wondir
Freris and feendis been but litil in sundir
For parde oftyn tyme yee haue herd telle .
How that a frere was rauysshid to helle
In his spiryte as by avisioun̄
And as an aungel ladde hym vp and doun̄
To shewe hym the peynys that ther were
And in al the place saugh he not a frere
Of othir folk he saw ynough in wo .
Vnto this aungel spak the frere tho
Now sire quoth he haue frerys such a grace
That non of hem shal comyn in this place
Yis quoth this aun̄gel many a millyon
And to Sathanas ladde hym a doun̄
And of Sathanas saw he a tayle
Brodder than of a caryk the sayle
Hold vp thi tayle thou shalt see qdquod he
Showe forth thy nars and let the frere see
Where is the nest of freris in this place
And er half a furlong way of space
Right so as bees swarme out of an hyue
Out of the deuyls ars ther gan dryue
Twenty thousand freris on a route
And thurghout swarme al aboute
And cam agayn als fast as thei may gon̄
And in his ars thei creptyn euerichon̄
He clappid to his tayle ageyn and lay stille
This frere whan he lokid had his fille
Vppon the turment of this sory place
His spiryte god receyuyd in his grace
Vnto his body ageyn and than he wook
But neuyr the lesse yit for fere he quooke
God saue yow alle sauf this cursid frere
My prologe wil I ende in this manere

Lordyngis ther is in yorkshire as I gesse
A mery cuntre callid holdernesse
In which ther went a lymytoᵘur about there
To preche in a kirke on his manere
And specially abouyn al thing
He excitid the poeple in his preching
To trentalys and to gyf for goddis sake
Ther with men myght holy housis make
Ther as dyuyne seruise is honouryd
Not ther yt is wastid and deuourid
Ne ther yt nedith not to be gyfyn
Als to possessioners that may wel lyuyn
Thankid be god in welthe and in habundan̄ce
Trentalys delyueryn said he from penaun̄ce
Here frendis soulys als wel old as yong
Yif so be that thei be hastily song
Not for to hold a preest ioly and gay
He singes but onys vppon a day
Delyuerth aa non̄ quoth he out the sawlys
Ful hard yt is with flesshhooke or with awlys
For to alure haukis and make hem come to hand
And harder yt is yee may wel vnderstand
Any of yow to wynne heuyn without good dedis
Yee most gyfe to vs pouer freris þer as gret nede is .
Now spede yow hastily for cristis sake
to kepe yoᵘur soulys fro the peynys of þe feendis blake
And whan the frere had seid his entent
With qui cum patre forth he went
Whan folk in the chirche had gyf hym what hem lyst
He went his way no lenger wold he rest
With skrippe and tippid staffe tukkid ful hye
And in euery hous he gan poure and prye .
And beggid mele chese or corne
His felawe had eke a staffe was tippid wᵗith horne .
A payre of tablis of Iuory
A poyntel polisshid ful fetisly
And wrot the name alway as he stood
Of any folk that gaf hem any good
Askaun̄ce þat he wold for hem pray
Yif vs a busshel whete or malt by your fay
A goddis kechil or ellis a trip of chese
Or ellys what yow list yee shal not þ̉eron lese
A goddis half peny or a messe peny
Or gyf vs of your brawne gif yee haue any
A dagoun̄ of your blanket leef dame
Oure sustir deere lo I wryte your name
Bacoun̄ or boef or such thing as yee fynd
A sturdy harlot went ay hem behynd
That was his hostys man and bar his sakke
And what men gaf hem layd yt on his bakke
And whan he was out at the dore anon
He planyd away the namys euerichon
That he before had wretyn in his tablis
He seruyd hem with truphlis and with fablis
Nay thou lixt thou Sommonoᵘur qdquod this frere
Pees quoth oure host for cristis moder dere
Telle forth thi tale spare not at al
So thryue I quoth the Sommonoᵘur so I shal
So long he went house by house til he .
Come to an hous ther he was wonyd to be
Refresshid more than at a hundrith places
Seeke lay the good w man whos þis place is .
Deus hic qdquod þe frere/Thomas frend good day .
And god yow saue he seid that best may
Thus seid this frere curtaysly and soft
Thomas he seid god yelde yow ful oft
Haue I vppon this benk faryn ful wel
Here haue I etyn many a mery meel
And fro the benk he drof away the catte
And laide doun̄ his potent and his hatte .
And eke his scrippe and sette hym soft adoun̄
His felawe was walkid in to the toun̄
Forthe with this knave and to that hostelry
Where he shoop hym that ilke nyght to ly .
O dere mayster qdquod this seeke man
How haue yee faryn sithen þat march began
I saugh yow not this fourtenyght and more
God wot qdquod he labourid haue I ful sore
And specially for thi saluacyoun̄
Haue I said many a precyous orysoun̄
And for othir good freendis god hem blisse
I haue þis day doon̄ at your chirche a messe
And said a sermoun̄ aftir symple witte
Not al aftir the text of holy wrytte
For yt is hard to yow as I suppose
Therfore I wil teche yow al the glose
Glosyng is a glorious thing certayn
For the lettir saith so as clerkis sayn
Ther haue I taught hem to be charitable
And to spend theire good ther as is resonable
And I saw oure dame where is she
Yondir in the yerd I trowe she be
Said the man and she wil come anon̄
Ey mayster welcome be yee by saynt Iohn̄
Seid the wyfe how fare yee hertily
The frere arisith ful curtaysly
And hir embrasid in his armys narwe
And kissid hir skyttirlich as a sparwe
With his lippys dame qdquod he right wel
And your seruaunt am I euerydel
I pray god yow saue bothe soule and lyfe
Yit saw I not this day so fayre a wyfe
In al the chirche so god saue me
Ye god amendethe faultys qdquod she
Algatis welcome be yee by my fay
Graund mercy dame that haue I foun̄dyn alway
But of your gret goodnesse by your leue
I wold pᵃray yow that yee wold not yow greue
I wil with thomas speke a litel throwe
Thise curatis ful necligent been and slowe
To grope tendirly a conscience
In shrift and in preching is my diligence
And study in Petris wurdis and in Paulis
I walk and fissh cristen soulys
To yeld IħuIhesu crist his ꝓpropre rent
To sprede his wurdis is al myn̄ entent
Now by your leue O dere mayster said she
Chidis hym wel for seynt charitee
He is als angry as is a pissonyre
Þough he haue al that he can desire
Þough I hym hele on nyghtis and make hym warm
And ouyr ley my legge or myn̄ arm̄
He gronyth lyke oure boor in oure sty
Othir disport of hym non̄ haue I .
O thomas ieo vous dy thomas
Seid this frere this is an hard caas
This makis the feend this most be amendid
Ire is a thing that hy god diffendid
And therof wil I speke a wurd or two
Now quoth the wyfe or that yee forther go
What wil yee dyne I wil go ther about
Now dame qdquod he ieo vous dy . saunz dout
Haue I not but of a capoun̄ the lire .
And of your soft bred not but a shyre
And aftir that a piggis hed
But that I ne wold no beste for me were ded
Than had I with yow homly sufficiaunce
I am a man of litil susteynaun̄ce
My spiryte hath his fostryng in the bible
So redy and penybly is ay the body
To walke that my stomak is distroyd
I pray yow dame that yee be not anoyd
Þough I to yow my counsel so frendly shewe
By god I nold telle yt but a fewe
Now syr quoth she but one wurd or þat yee go
My child is ded within thise wykes two
Sone aftyr that yee went out of this toun̄
His deth saw I by Reuelacyoun̄
Seid this frere ; at home in my dortour
I dar wel say er that half an hour
Aftyr his deth I saw hym born to blisse
In myn visioun so god me blisse
So did oure sacristeyn and our fermerere
That haue been I trew freris fyfty yeere
Thei may now thankid be god of his lone
Makyn hir Iubile and walkyn allone

(base) Withouten noyse or clateryng of belles
(base) Te Deum was oure song and no thyng elles

(base) Thankynge hym of his reuelacioun
(base) For sire and dame trusteth me right wel
(base) Oure orisons been wel moore effectuel
(base) And moore we seen of cristes secree thynges
(base) Than burell folk althogh that they were kynges

(base) Yaf vs ensample of fastyng and prayeres

(base) Ful many a pound yet fare I neuere the bet
(base) Certeyn my good haue I almoost biset
(base) Farwel my gold for it is al ago

(base) What nedeth yow diuerse freres seche
(base) What nedeth hym that hath a parfit leche
(base) To sechen othere leches in the town
(base) Youre inconstance is youre confusioun
Hold than me or oure couent
To pray for yow insufficiaunt
Thomas ; that Iape is not wurth a myte
Youre malady is for we haue to lyte
For I sey pleynly without more aduysement
That your testament is no wurth a bent
Þat is to sey I gyf þat freris a quarter of otys
And I gyf to that couent xxiv . grotys
I gyf that frere a peny let hym go
Nay nay thomas yt may not be so
What is a thing departid twelf
Parde quoth þis frere onehed in hym self
Is more strong than whan yt is discateryd
Thomas of me thou shalt not be flateryd
Thou woldist haue oure labour al for nought
The hygh god that al this world haþ wrought
Seith that euery werkman is wurthi his hire
Thomas of youre tresoure I nought desire
As for my self but al oure couent
That to pray for yow is ay so diligent
And for beldyn cristis owne chirche
Thomas yif yee wil lern̄ to wirche
Of beldyng vppon chirchis ; yee may fynde
Of yt be god in thomas lyfe of ynde
Yee ligge here ful of angre and of Ire
With the which thethe deuyl settis yoᵘur hert on fyre
And chidyn here so holy and so Innocent
Youre wyfe that is so meke and pacyent

To Ianuary ; whan that he for hir sent
Vp rysith damyan the next morwe
Al passid was his seeknesse and his sorwe
He kembith hym he prunyth hym and pykith
And dooth al that his lady lustith ⁊and likyth
And eke to Ianuary he goth als lowe
As euer did a dogge for the bowe
He is so pleasaunt to euery Man
For craft is al who so do yt can
That euery wight is fayn to speke hym good
And fully in his ladyes grace he stood
Thus lete I damyan aboute his nede
And in my tale forth I wil procede
Sum clerkis holdyn that felicytee
Stondith in delyte and therfore he
The noble Ianuary with al his myght
In honest wyse as longith to a knyght
Shoop hym to lyue ful delicyously
His housyng and his array al honestly
To his degree was made as a kyngis
And among othir of his honest thingis
He hadde a garden al wallid with ston
So fayre a garden wot I nowgher non
For out of doute I verraly suppose
That he þat wrot the Romaun̄ce of the Rose
Ne couth of yt the beaute wel deuyse
Ne preapus myght not suffyce
Þough he be god of gardynes for to telle
The beaute of the gardyn and the welle
That stood vndir a laurere alwey grene
Ful oftyn tyme he pluto and his queene
Proserpina and al hir fayrye
Disportyn hem and makyn melodye
Aboute that welle and daun̄sid as men told
This noble knyght this Ianuary the old
Such deynte hath in yt to walke and pley
That he wil suffre no wight to bere the key
Sauf he hym self for of the smal wyket
He bar alway of siluer a clyket
With which whan þat hym lyst vnshette
And whan that he wold pay his wyfe his dette
In somer seson thidir wold he go
And may his wyfe and no wight but þei two
And thingis which were not doon̄ in bedde
He in the gardyn̄ perfourmyd them ⁊and spedde
And in this wyse many a mery day
Lyuyd this Ianuary and fressh may
But worldly ioye may not ay endure
To Ianuary ne to no no worldly creature
O subitan happe O thou fortune vnstable
I lyken the to the scorpyoıı̄un deceyuable
That flaterist with thyne hed whan þᵘ wil sting
Thi tayle is deth thurgh thyn̄ envemynyng
O brytel ioye O sweet poyson queynt
O thou that subtily canst peynt
Thi giftes ; vndir the hewe of stedfastnesse
Þurgh which þou deceyuyst bothe more ⁊and lesse
Whi hast thou Ianuary thus deceyuyd
And haddist hym for thi ful frend receyuyd
And now thou hast bereft hym boþe his eyen
For sorwe of whiche desireth he to dyen
Allas that this noble Ianuary fre
Amyddis his lust and his prosperyte
Is waxen blynd and subitanly
He wepith and weylith pitously
And therwithal the fyre of ielousye
Lest that his wyfe shuld falle in som folye
So brent his hert that he wold fayne
That som man bothe hym and hir had slayne
For neuyr aftir his deth ne in his lyfe
Ne wold he that she were loue ne wyfe
But euer ben as widue in clothis blake
Sool as the trew turtil þat hath lost hir make
But at the last aftir a moneth or twey
His sorwe began to asswage the sooth to sey
For whan he wist yt may non̄ othir be
He paciently took his aduersyte
Sauf out of doute he may not forgon̄
That he ne was ielous euer in on
Whiche ielousye yt was euermore so outᵃragious
That nouthir in halle ne in non̄ othir hous
Ne in non othir place neuer the mo
He ne wold suffre hir to ryde ne go
But yif that he had hand on hir alway
For which ful ofte wepis the fressh may
That louyth damyan so benignely
That she mot outhir dye subitanly
Or ellis perseuere in hir sorwe at þe lest
She waytith alway whan þat hir hert wold brest
Vppon that othir side damyan
Becomyn is the sorwefullest man
That euer was for nouthir nyght ne day
Ne myght he speke a wurd to fressh may
As to his purpose of no such matere
But yif that Ianuary most heere
That hadde an hand vppon hir euermore
For which this damyan sighid sore
And neuyr the lesse by writyng to and fro
Thei were accordid what thei shuld doo
And eke by pryuee signe wist he what she ment
And she knewe of the fyne of his entent
O Ianuary what myght the avayle
Though thou myght see als fer as shippis sayle
For als good yt is a blynd man deceyuyd to be
As to be deceyuyd whan that he may see
Lo argus which þat hadde an hundrith eyen
For al that he couthe poure or pryen
Yit was he blynt god wot so be mo
That wene ful wistly that yt is not so
Passe ouer is an ease and say no more
The fressh may the which I spak of yore
In warme wax hath enpryntid þe clyket
That Ianuary bar of the smal wyket
By which in to his gardyn oftyn he went
And damyan that knew al his entent
The clyket countirfetid pryuely
Ther was no more to sey but hastily
Sum wondir by his clyket shal betyde
Whiche yee shul here yif yee wil abyde
O noble ouyde sooth sais thou god wot
What sleight yt is of loue long and hot
What louere is this world withinne
That castith by sleight his loue to wynne
That he nyl fynde yt out in som manere
By pyramus and tysbe men may leere
Though thei were kept ful long streit oủeral
Thei been accordid rownyng thurgh a wal
Ther no wight couth haue foundyn out such a sleight
But new to the purpos ; that dayes eight
Were passid of the moneth of Iule befel
That Ianuary hath caught so gret a wil
Thurgh eggyng of his wyfe hym to play
In his gardyne and no wight but thei twey
That in a morwe vn to his may seid he
Rise vp my loue my wyfe my lady fre
The turtil voice is herd my douve sweete
The wynter is gon̄ with alle his raynes wete
Come forth now with thyne eyen columbyne
How fayre be thi breestis therin is wyne
The gardyn is enclosid al a boute
Come forth my white spouse saunz doute
Thou hast me woundid in myn̄ hert o wyfe
No spotte ne was ther in the in al thi lyfe
Come forth and lat vs take oure disport
I chese the for my wyfe and my confort
Such olde lewde wurdis vsid he
On damyan a signe made she
That he shuld go before with his clyket
This damyan hath openyd the wyket
And he in styrt and that in such manere
That no wight myght yt see ne here
And stylle he satte vndir a buske anon
This Ianuary as blynd as is a ston
With may in his hand and no wight mo
Into this fressh gardyn is a go
And clappid to the wyket subitanly
Now wyfe qdquod he here nys but thou and I
Thou art the creature that I best loue
For by that lord IħuIhesu that sittes a boue
I hadde leuer dyen vppon a knyfe
Than the offendyn dere trewe wyfe
For goddis sake thynke þat I yow ches
Not for no couetyse douteles
But only for the loue that I hadde to the
And þough þat I be old and may not see
Beth to me trewe and I wil telle yow whi
Certys thynges shal yee wynne therby
Furst loue of cryste and to your self honour
And al myne heritage toun̄ and tour
I gyf to yow ; makys chartris as yow lyst
This shal be doon̄ to Morwe or the sonne ryst
So wystely god bryng my soule to blisse
And I pray yow vppon this couenaunt Me kysse
And þough that I be ielous wyte me nought
Yee been so depe enpryntid in my thought
That whan I considre your beaute
And therwith al the vnlikly age of Me
I may not certys þough I shuld dye
Forbere to be out of your companye
For verray loue this is without doute
Now kysse me wyfe and lat vs Rome aboute
This fressh may whan she thise wurdis herd
Benignely vnto Ianuary answerd
But furst and forward she began to wepe
I haue quoth she a soule for to kepe
Als wel as yee ; and also myne honour
And my wyfehod thilk tendre flour
Which that I haue assurid in yoᵘur hand
Whan that the preest to yow my body bond
Wherfore I wil answere in this manere
With leue of yow my lord so deere
I pray god that dawe neuer that day
That I ne sterve as foule as womman may
Yif euer I do vnto my kyn that shame
Or ellis enpayre so my name
That I be fals ; and yif I do that lakke
Do strype me and put me in a sakke
And in the next ryuer do me drenche
I am a gentil womman and no wenche
Whi speke yee thus ; but Men been euer vntrewe
And wommen haue þei repreuyd euer of newe
Yee can non othir contynaun̄ce I leue
But euer speke to vs of vntrust and repreue
And with that wurd she saw where damyan
Satte in the buske ; and kowgh she began
And with hir fingyr a signe made she
That damyan shuld clymbe vp in to a tre
That chargid was with frute and vp he went
For verraly he knewe al his entent
And euery signe that she couth make
Wel bettir than Ianuary hir owne make
For in a lettre she had told hym al
Of this mater how that he wirche shal
And thus I lete hym sytte in the pley
This Ianuary romyng and also may
Bright was the day and blew the firmament
Phebus of gold doun̄ his stremys hath sent
To glade euery floure with his warmnesse
He was that tyme in geminis as I gesse
But lytil of his declaracyoun̄
Of cancer Iouis exaltacioun̄
And befel that bright morwe tyde
That in the gardyn on the ferther side
Pluto that is the kyng of fayrye
And many a lady in his compaignye
Folwyng his wyfe queene proserpina
Which that he rauysshid out of ethena
Whils that she gadrid flourys in a mede
In claudian yee may the history rede
How in his grysly cart he hir sette
This kyng of fayrie doun̄ hym sette
Vppon a benke of turphis fayre and grene
And anon thus seid he to his queene
My wyfe qdquod he ther may no wight sey nay
The experience preuyth yt euery day
The tresoun̄ which that womman doos to man
Ten hundrith þousand historyes telle I can
Notable of your vntruthe and wrecchidnesse
O salamon richest of al richesse
Fulfillid of sapience and of worldly glory
Ful wurthi are thi wurdis to be in memory
To euery wight that wit and reson can
Thus preysid yit the bounte of a man
Among a thousand men yit fond I one
But of alle wommen yit fonde I neủer non̄
Thus said this kyng þat knewe yoᵘur wykkidnesse
And IħcIhesu filius syrach as I gesse
Ne spekith of yow but seldom Reuerence
The wild fyre and a corrupt pestilence
So falle vppon your bodyes yit this nyght
Ne see yee not this honourable knyght
Be cause allas that he is blynd and old
His owne man yit shal make hym cukwold
Lo where he sittis the lecchour in the tree
Now wil I graunt hymhym of my maieste
Vnto this olde wurthi blynd knyght
That he shal haue ageyn his eyen sight
Whan that his wyfe wil doon hym vilany
Than shal he knowe al hir harlotry
Bothe in repreef of hir and othir mo
Yee shal qdquod proserpyna and shal yee so
Now by my modir soule sir I swere
That I shal gyf hir sufficient answere
And to alle wommen aftir for hir sake
That þough thei be in any gyle I take
With face bold thei shal hem self excuse
And bere hem doun̄ that wold hem accuse
For lakke of answere non of vs shal dyen
Al þough yee had seen a thing with boþe yoᵘur eyen
Yit shal we so yt visage hardily
And wepe and swere and chide subtilly
That yee shul been als lewde as gees
What rekkith me of yoᵘur auctoritees
I wote wel that this Iew this salomon
Fond of vs wommen folys many on
But though he fond no good womman
Ther hath found many an othir man
Wommen ful good trewe and vertuous
Wittenesse of hym that duellys in cristis hous
With martyrdome that preuyd hir constaıı̄unce
The Romayn gestis makyn Remembraun̄ce
Of many a verry trewe wyfe also
But sir be not wroth al though yt be so
That he seid he fond no good womman
I pray take the sentence of Man
He ment thus that in soueraigne bounte
Ne is non̄ good nouthir he ne she
But for the verray god that nys but one
What make yee so mych of salomon
What þough he made a temple goddis hous ;
What þough he were riche and glorious ;
So made he eke a temple of fals goddis
Who myght doo a thing þat more forbed is ;
Parde als fayre as yee his name enplaastre
He was a lecchour and eke an Idolastre
And in his elde he verray god forsooke
And yif god ne hadde as saith the booke
Sparid hym for his fadir sake he shuld
Haue lost his Regne ; sauf þat god ne wold
I sette nought of al the vilanye
That he of wommen wrot a buttyrflye
I am a womman nede mot I speke
Or ellis swelle til my hert breke
For sithen he said that we been iangleressis
As euyr mot I brouke wel my tressis
I shal not spare for no curtasye
To speke hym harme þat spekith vs vilanye
Dame qdquod this pluto be no lenger wroth
I gyf yt vp ; but sithen I swore and oth
That I wold graunt hym his sight ageyn
My wurd shal stand that warne I yow certeyn
I am a kyng yt sittith me not to lye
And I am a queene qdquod she of fayrye
Hir answer shal she haue I vndirtake
Lat vs no mo wurdis of yt make
For sooth I wil no lenger yow contrary
Now lat vs turne ageyn to Ianuary
That in the gardyn with his fayre may
Syngith meryer than a popyn Iay
Yow loue I best and shal and othir non̄
So long aboute the aleys is he gon̄
Til he come ageyn thilk pirye
Where as this damyan sittith ful merye
And hygh among the fressh leuys grene
This fressh may that is bright and shene
Gan for to sighen and said allas my syde
Now sir quoth she for ought that may betyde
I most haue of thise perys that I se
Or I most dye so sore longith me
To etyn of the smale peris grene
Help for hir loue that is of heuyn queene
I telle yow wel a womman in my plyte
May haue to frute so gret an appetyte
That she may dye but yif of yt haue
Allas quoth she that I ne had here a knaue
That couth clymbe ; allas allas quoth he
For I am blynd ; ye sir no force qdquod she
So that I my feet myght sette vppon your bakke
Certys quoth he therin shal be no lakke
Myght I yow help with myn̄ hert blood
He stoupid doun and on his bakke she stood
And caught by a twist and vp she goth
Ladyes I pray yow that yee be not wroth
I can not glose I am a rude man
And subitanly anon̄ this damyan
Gan pulle vp the smok and in he throng
And whan that pluto saw this gret wrong
To Ianuary he gaf ageyn his sight
That he myght se als wel as euer he myght
And whan that he had caught his sight ageyn
Ne was ther neuer man of thing so fayn
But on his wyfe his thought was euer mo
And to the tree he cast his eyen two
And saw that damyan his wyfe had dressid
In such wyse as may not be expressid
But yif I wold speke vncurtayslye
And vp he gaf a roryng and a crye
As dooth the modir whan the child shal dye
Out help harrow allas he gan to crye
O strong lady stoor what doost thou
And she answerd ʆsir what eylith yow
Haue pacience and reson in your mynde
I haue yow helpid of bothe yoᵘur eyen blynde
Vppon peril of my soule I shal not lyen
This was me taught to hele with yoᵘur eyen
Was ther no thing bettir to make yow to see
Than stroglyng with a man vppon a tree
God wot I did yt in ful good entent
Strouglyng qd he ; but algate in yt went
God gyf yow bothe a shamys deth to dyen
Yee did amys I saw yt with myn eyen
And ellis be I hangid by the hals
Than is qdquod she my medicyne al fals
For certanly yif that yee myght see
Yee wold not sey thise wurdis to me
Yee haue som glymryng and no ꝑperfecte sight
I se qdquod he als wel as euer I myght
Thankid be god with bothe myn eyen two
And by my trouthe me thought yee didyn so
Yee ; the mase the mase good ʆsir qdquod she
This thank haue I for that I made yow see
Allas ʆsir quoth she that euer I was so kynde
Now dame qdquod he lat yt passe out of mynde
Come doun̄ my loue and yif I haue myssaid
God help me so as I am euyl a paid
But by my fadirs soule I wend þat I had seen̄
How that this damyan had by the lyen
And that thi smok had lyggyn vppon thi brest
Yee sir qd she yee may wene as yow lest
But sir a man that wakith out of his sleep
He may not subitanly wel take keepe
Vppon a thing ne see yt so perfectely
Til he be adawid verrayli
Right so a man þat long hath blynd be
Ne may not subtanly so wel see
Furst whan his sight is comyn newe ageyn
As he that hath a day or two seyn
Til that youre sight sattlid be a while
Ther may ful many a sight yow begyle
Be war I pray yow for by heuyn kyng
Ful many a man wenyth to se a thing
That is al an othir than yt semyth
He that mysconceyueth mysdemyth
And with that wurd she lepith doun̄ fro þe tr
This Ianuary who is glad but he
He kissith hir and clippith hir ful ofte
And on hir wombe he stryketh hir ful softe
And to his palace hom he hath hir lad
Now god good men I pray you to be glad
Thus endid is my tale of Ianuary
God blisse vs and his modir seynt mary

div.l:
Explicit fabula mercatoris ⁊and sub-
sequenter incipit prohemium fabule
Armigeri hoc modo sequente
Ey goddis mercy seid oure host tho
Now such a wyfe I pray god kepe me fro
Lo such sleightis and subtilitees
In wommen been ; and ay as besy as bees
Been thei ; vs sely men for to deceyue
And from a sooth ay wil thei weyue
Ey this merchauntz tale preuyth weel
But doutles als trew as any steel
I haue a trewetrewe wyfe þough she poure be
But of hir blabbyng a shrewe is she
And yit she hath an hep of vices Mo
Therof no force lat alle such þinges go
But wot yee what in coun̄cel be yt seid
Me rewith sore that I am to hir teyd
For yif I shuld rekne euery vice
Whiche that she hath Iwis I were to nyce
And cause whi ; yt shuld reportid be
And told to hir of sum of this meyne
Of whom yt nedith not to declare
Sithen wommen can outyn such chaffare
And eke my wytte suffiseth not therto
To telle al wherfore my tale is doo
Esquyer com neer yif that yoᵘur wille be
And say som what for certys yee
Can theron as mekil as any man
Nay fro quoth he but such thingys as I can
With hertly wil I wil not be Rebelle
Ageyn your lust a tale for to telle
Hold me excusid yif I speke amys
My wil is good and my tale is this

Explicit prohemium fabule Armi-
geri ⁊et subsequenter narrat fabulām
suam hoc modo sequente .
AT sarry in the lond of tartarye
Ther dwellid a kyng that werreid Russye
Thurgh which ther died many a doughti man
This noble kyng clepid was cambuscan
Which in his tyme was of gret renoun̄
That ther was nowhghwher in no regyoun̄
So excellent a lord in al thing
Hym lakkith not that longith to a kyng
As of the secte of which he was born̄
He kept his lay to which that he was sworn̄
And therto he was hardy wise and riche
And pitous and iust alway in liche
Sooth of his wurd benygne and honourable
Of his curage as any centre stable
Yong fressh and strong in armys desirous
As any bachillere in al his hous
A fayre ꝑpersone he was and fortunate
And kept so wel his royal eastate
That ther nas nowghte such a man
As was this noble kyng callid cambuscan

IN feith esquyer thou hast the wel quytte
I preyse gentilly and right wel thi wytte
Quoth the frankleyn consideryng thi yowthe
So felyngly thou spekist sir I alow the
As to my dome ther nys non̄ that is here
Of eloquence that shal be thi pere
Yif that thou lyue god gif the good chaun̄ce
And in vertu send the contynuaun̄ce
For of thi speche I haue gret deynte
I haue a sone and by the trynytee
I had leuer than xxᵗⁱ pound wurth of land
Þough yt were right now fallyn in my hand
He were a man of such discrecyoun̄
As that yee been fy on possessioun̄
But yif aman be vertuous with al
I haue my sone snybbid and yit I shal
For he to vertues lystith not to entende
But for to play at dyse and to dispende
And lese al that he hath is his vsage
And he had leuer talkyn with a page
Than to comown̄ with any gentil wight
Where he myght lere gentilnesse of right
A strawe for oure gentilnesseqdquod oure host
What frankleyn̄ sir parde wel thou wost
That ich of yow mot tellyn at the lest
A tale or two ; or brekyn his byhest
That know I wel qdquod the frankleyn certeyn
I pray yow haue yt at no disdeyn
Though I to this man spak a wurd or two
Telle thou thi tale without wurdis Mo .
Gladly qdquod he sir host I wil obeye
Vnto your wil now herkyn what I seye
I wil not yow contrary in no wyse
As ferforth as that my wytte wil suffice
I pray to god that yt may please yow
Than wot I wel that yt is good ynowgh

div.l: Thise olde gentil bretoıı̄uns in þer dayes
Of dyuersez aduentures made her layes
Rymyd in here furst bretoun̄ tonge
Which layes with hir instrumentz thei songe
Or ellis rede hem for her pleasaun̄ce
And one of hem haue I in Rel Remembraıı̄unce
Which I shal seyn with good wil as I can
But sirs by cause that I am but a burell Man
At my begynnyng furst I yow beseke
Haue me excusid yif I rudely speke
I lernyd neuer rethoryk certeyn
The englissh that I speke yt most be pleyn
I ne slept neuer on the mount pernaso
Ne lernyd neuer Marcus tulliꝫus ne cithero

nec fonte labra prolui caballino
nec in bicipiti ꝑpernaso me Meumin͗e s̄mpniasse
Colours ne know I non̄ without drede
But such colours as growyn in the Mede
Or ellis such as Men dyen or paynt
Colours of Rethoryk been to quaynt
My spiryte felith not of such matere
But yif yow list my tale shul yee here
In Almaryk that callid is bretayn
Ther was a knyght þat lyuyd ⁊and did his payn
To serue a lady in his best wyse
And many a labour and many a gret enprise
He for his lady wrought or she were wonne
For she was the fayrest one vndre þe sonne
And eke therto comyn of so hy kyndred
That wel vnneth durst this knyght for drede
Tellen hir his wo his peyn and his distresse
But at the last she for his worthynesse
And namely for his meke obeisaun̄ce
Hath such a pytte caught of his penaun̄ce
That pryuely she fel to his accord
To take hym for hir husbond and hir lord
Of such lordship as men haue ouer þeir wyfes
And for to lede in more blisse their lyfes
Of his fre wil he swore hir as a knyght
That neuer in al his lyfe he day ne nyght
Shuld take vppon hym maysterly
Agayns hir wil ne kythe hir ielousy
But hir obey and folwe hir wil in al
As any louere to his lady shal
Sauf that the name of soueraignte
That wold he haue for shame of his degre
She thankid hym and with gret humblenesse

In myrthe and iolyte oure lyfe to lyuyn
And lightly as yt comyth so wil we yt dispende
Ey goddis precious dignyte who wende
This day that we shuld haue had so fayr a gᵃrace
But myght this gold be caried from this place
Home to myn̄ house or ellis to yourys
For wel I wot that al this gold is ourys
Than were we in hygh felicitee
But trewely by day yt may not bee
Men wold sey that we were theefis strong
And for oure owne tresour doo vs hong
This tresour most be caryed by nyght
Als wysely and as slyly as yt myght
Wherfore I rede that cutte among vs alle
Be drawe ; and lete se where yt shal falle
He that the cutte happith with hert blythe
Shal renne to the toun̄ and that as swythe
To bryng vs bred and wyne ful pryuely
And two of vs shal kepe ful subtily
The tresour wel ; and yif he wil not tary
Whan yt is nyght we wil the tresour cary
By one assent where that vs liketh best
That one of hem the cutte brought in his fest
And bad hem drawe and loke where yt wil falle
And yt fel on the yongest of them alle
And forth toward the toun̄ he went anon̄
And als sone as that he was gon̄
That on of them spak thus vn to that othir
Thou wost wel that thou art my sworn̄ brothir
Thi profyte wil I telle the anon
And also thou wost wel oure felawe is gon̄
And here is gold and that gret pleynte
That shuld be departid among vs thre
But Neuer the lesse yif I can shape yt so
That yt were departid betwix vs two
Haue I not doon̄ a frendis turn̄ to the
That othir answerd I ne wot how þat myght be
He wot wel the good is with vs twey
What shal we doon̄ what shal we sey
Shal yt be coun̄sel seid the furst shrewe
And I shal telle the in wurdis fewe
How we shal doon̄ and bring yt wel aboute
I graunt qdquod that othir out of doute
That by my trouthe I wil the not bewreye
Now quoth the furst we be but tweye
And yit two of vs shal strenger be than one
Looke whan that he is sette and þat anon
Arise as thou wold with hym play
And I shal renne hym thurgh the sidis tway
Whils that thou strugglist with hym as in game /
And with thi dagger looke þou do the same
And than shal al this gold departid be
My dere frend betwix me and the
Than may we bothe oure lustis fulfille
And play at the dyce right at oure own wille
And thus accordid been thise shrewis twey
To sle the thridde as yee haue herd me sey
The yongest which went vn to the toun̄
Ful ofte in his hert he musith vp and doun̄
On the beaute of thise floreyns newe and bright
O lord god qdquod he yif so were þat I myght
Haue al this tresour to my self allon
Ther nys no man that lyuys vndir the trone
Of god ; that shuld lyue meryer than I
And at the last the feend oure enemy
Put in his thought that he shuld poysoıı̄un bye
With the which he myght sleen̄ his felaws tweye
For whi the feend fond in hym such lyuyng
That he was leef to sorwe hem bryng
For this was vttirly his ful entent
To sleen̄ hem bothe and neuer to repent
And forth he goth no lenger wold he tary
In to the toun̄ vn to apotecary
And prayd hym that he to hym wold selle
Som poyson that he myght his rattys kylle
And eke ther was a polcat in his hawe
That as he seid his capoıı̄uns his capoıı̄uns had slawe
And seid he wold wrekyn hym yif he myght
On vermyn that distroyd hym day and nyght
The apotecary answerd and yee shal haue
A thing that as god my soule saue
In al this world ne is ther no creature
That etyn or drynkyn of this confecture
Not but the moun̄taun̄ce of a corn̄ of whete
And he shal anon̄ his lyfe for lete
And sterue he shal and that in lasse while
Than thou wil gon a paas not a myle
The poysoıı̄un is so strong and so violent
This cursid man has in his hand yt hent
This poysoıı̄un in a box ; and sithen he ran
In to the next strete vn to a man
And borwid hym large botels thre
And in the two his poyson pouryd he
The thridde he kept clene for his drynk
For al the nyght he shoop hym for to swynk
In cariage of the gold out of that place
And whan this riotour with sory grace
Hadde fillid with wyne his grete botels thre
To his felawis ageyn repayrith he
What nedis yt to sermoun̄ yt more
For right as thei had cast his deth before
Right so thei haue hym slayn and that anon̄
And whan that this was doon̄ þan spak that on
Now lete vs drynk and sitte and make vs mery
And aftirward wil we his body bury
And aftirward happenyd hym par caas
To take the botel wherin the poyson was
And drank and gaf his felaw drynk also
For which anon thei dyed bothe two
But certis I suppose that auycen
Wrot neuer in no canon ne Innocen
Mo wondir sorwis of poysonyng
Thus haues this wrecchis two her endyng
Thus endid been thise homycidis two
And eke the fals enpoysoner also
Of cursid synne fallith cursidnesse
O traytours homycidis . O . wykkidnesse
O glotonye lecchery . O hasardye
Thou blasphemer of crist with vilenye
Of othis grete of vsage and of pryde
Allas mankynde how may yt be
That to thi creatour which þat the wrought
And with his precious blood the bought
That art so fals and so vnkynd allas
Now good men godforgif you your trespas
And war yow fro the synne of auarice
My holy pardon may yow alle warice
So that yee offre noblys or sterlingis
Or ellis siluer sponys brochis or ryngis
Bowith your hed vndir this holy bulle
Comyth vp ye wyfes offrith your wulle
Your namys I entre here in my rolle anon
Vnto the blisse of heuyn shal yee gon
I yow assoyle by my high powere
Yee that wil offre as clene and as clere
As yee were born̄ and lo sirs thus I preche
And ihūIhesu that is oure soule leche
So graunt yow this pardon to receyue
For that is best I wil not yow deceyue
But sirs a wurd forgat I in my tale
I haue reliquees and pardoıı̄un in my male
Als fayre as any man in england
Which were me gyffyn by the popis hand
Yif any of yow wil of deuocyoun̄
Offre and haue myne absolucyoun̄
Comyth forth a non̄ and kneelith here a doun̄
And yee shal haue here gret pardoun̄
Or ellis takis pardoıı̄un as yee wende
Al newe and fressh at euery townys ende
So that yee offre alwey newe and
Noblys and penyes which that been good ⁊and trewe
Yt is an honour to euerich that is here
That yee may haue a sufficient pardonere
To assoyle yow in cuntre as I ryde
For aduenturis the which may betide
Par aduenture ther may falle one or two
Doun̄ of his hors and breke his necke in two
Lo such a sort yt is to yow alle
That I am in your felawship falle
That may assoyle yow bothe more and lesse
Whan that the soule shal fro the body passe
I rede that oure host shal begynne
For he is most volupt in synne
Come forth sir host and offre furst a non
And thou shal kisse the reliquees euerichon .
Ye for a grote anon vnbukle thi purs
Nay nay quoth he than haue I cristis curs
Let be for yt shal not be so theech
Thou woldist make me kisse thyne olde brech
And swere yt were a Relique of a seynt
Though þat yt were with thi fundament depaynt
But by the croyce which þat seynt helen fond
I wold I had thi colyoıı̄uns in my hand
In stede of Reliques and of sanctuary
Lete kytte hem of and I wil help the hem to cary
Thei shal be shryned in an hoggis toord
This pardoner answerd not a wurd
So wroth he was that no thing wold he say
No lenger quoth oure host ne lyst me to play
With the ne with non̄ angry man
But right anon the wurthi knyght began
Whan that he saw that al the poeple lowgh
Nomore of this for yt is right Inowgh
Sir pardoner be glad and mery of chere
And yee sir host that been to me so dere
I pray yow that yee kisse the pardonere
And pardoner I pray the drawe the neere
And as we did lat vs laugh and play
Anon thei kissid and ridyn forth her way

div.l: A merchaunt whilom duellied at seynt denys
Þᵗat Riche was which men held ful wyse
A wyfe he hadde of excellent beaute
And compaynable and reuerent was she
Which is a thing that causith more dispence
Than wurth is al the chere and Reuerence
That men doon hem at festis and at daun̄cys
Suych salutacyouns and contenaun̄cis
Passyn as dooth the shadow on a wal
But wo is hym that most pay for al
The sely husbond algate he must pay
He most vs clothe and vs array
Al for his owne wurship richely
In which array we daun̄ce Iolily
And yif that he may not par aduenture
Or ellis no such dispensis endure
But thinkis yt is al wast and lost
Than most an othir pay for oure cost
And lene vs gold and that is ꝑperilous
This noble merchaunt held a noble hous
For which he hadde al day gret repayre
For his largesse and for his wyfe was fayre
What wondir ys yt ; but herkyn to my tale
Among alle his gestis gret and smale
Ther was a monk a fayr man and a bold
I trowe thrytti wynter he was old
That euer in one was drawyng to that place
This yong monk that was so fayre of face
Acqueynted was with the good man
Sithen that furst her knowlech be gan
That in hous as famulier was he
As is possible any man to be
And for als mekil as this good man
And eke this monk of the which I began
Were bothe two born̄ in a village
The monk hym claymyth as for cosynage
And he agayn seith not onys nay
But als glad was therof as foule of day
For to his herte yt was gret pleasaun̄ce
Thus thei ben knytte with etern alliaun̄ce
And ich of hem gan othir for to assure
Of brothirhede whils that her lyfis endure
Fre was dan Iohn and manly of dispence
As in that hous and ful of diligence
To do largesse and gret costage
He not forgate to gyf the lest page
In al that hous but aftir her degree
He gaf the lord and sithen al the meynee
Whan that he come som maner of honest thing
For which thei were als glad of his comyng
As foule is fayn whan the sonne vp risith
No more of this as now for yt suffisith
But so befel this merchaunt on a day
Shoop hym to make redy his array
Toward the toun̄ of brygges for to fare
To byen ther a porcyon of ware
For which he hath to parys sent a non
A messager for his cosyn dan Iohn
Oure dere cosyn ful of curtesy
With hym brought he a Iubbe of maluesy
And eke an othir ful of fyne vernage
And volatyle as ay was his vsage
And thus I lete hem ete and drynk and play
This merchaunt and this monk a day or tway
The thridde day this merchaunt vp rysith
And on his nedis hym sadly aviseth
And vp in to his coun̄tyng hous goth he
To rekken with hym self as wel may be
Of thilk yeer how that yt stood
And how that he dispendid had his good
And yif that he encresid were or non̄
His bookis and his baggis manyon
He leyth before hym on his countyng boorde
Ful riche was his tresour and his hord
For which ful fast he his countre dore shette
And eke he nold no man shuld hym lette
Of his accom̄ptis in the mene while tyme
And thus he sat til yt was passid pryme
Dan Iohn was rysen in the morwe also
And in the gardyn̄ walkid to and fro
And hath his thingis seid ful holily
This good wyfe cam walkyng pryuely
In to the gardyn ther he walkid soft
And hym salueth as she hath doon̄ oft
A mayden child come in hir companye
Which as she lyst she may gouerne and guye
For yit vndir the yerde was the mayde
O dere cosyn myn dan Iohn̄ she saide
What eylith yow thus erly for to aryse
Nece he saith yt ought ynoug suffice
Fyue hourys to slepe on a nyght
But yif yt were for an old pallid wight
As been thise weddid men that ligge and dare
As in a fourme sittys a wery hare
Þᵗat were al distraught wᵗith houndis gret ⁊and smale
But deere Nece whi been̄ yee so pale
I trowe certis that your goodman
Hath yow labourid sithen þat nyght began
That yow were nede to rest hastily
And with that wurd he lough ful meryly
And of his owne thought he wex red
This fayre wyfe began to shake hir hed
And seid thus ye god wot al quoth she
Nay cosyn myn yt stondith not so with me
For by god that gaf me soule and lyfe
In al the realme of Fraun̄ce is ther no wyfe
That lesse lust hath to that sory play
For I may syng allas and wel away
That I was born̄ but to no wightqdquod she
Ne dar I telle how yt standis with me
Wherfore I thinke out of this land to wende
Or ellis of my self to make an ende
So ful am I of drede and eke of care
This monke began vppon hir to stare
And said allas my nece god for bede
That yee for any sorwe or any drede
For do your self but tellis me your greef
Par aduenture I may in your myscheef
Coun̄sel and help and therfore tellys me
Al your anoye for yt shal be secree
For on my portos I make an othe
That Neuer in my lyfe for leef ne lothe
Ne shal I of no coun̄sel yow bewreye
The same ageyn to yow I seye
But by god and by this portos I swere
Þough men wold me in to pecys tere
Ne shal I neuer for to go to helle
Bewrey wurd or thing that yee me telle
Not for no cosynage ne for non alliaun̄ce
But verraly for loue and affiaun̄ce
Thus thei been sworn̄ and hervppon kist
And ilk of hem told othir what hem lyst
Cosyn qdquod she yif I had a space
As I haue non̄ and namely in this place
Than wold I telle yow a legend of of my lyfe
That I haue suffrid sithen I was a wyfe
With my husbond ; alþough he be yoᵘur cosyn
Nay qdquod this monk by god and by seynt martyn
He is no more cosyn vn to me
Than is this leef that hengis on this tree
I clepe hym so be seynt denyse in Fraun̄ce
To haue more cause of acquayntaun̄ce
Of yow which I haue louyd especially
Aboue alle wommen sikirly
This swere I yow by my professioun̄
Tellith your greef lest he com a doun̄
And hastis yow and go your wey a non̄
My dere Loue qdquod she O dan Iohn̄
Ful leef me were this coun̄sel to hide
But out yt must yt may no lenger abide
My husbond is to me the werst man
That euer was sithen that the world began
But sithen I am a wyfe yt sittys not to me
To telle no wight of oure pryuetee
Nouthir in bedde ne in non othir place
God sheld I shuld telle yt for his grace
A wyfe shal not sey of hir husbond
But al honour as I can vndirstond
Sauf vnto yow this mych telle I shal
So help me god he is not wurth at al
In no degree the valu of a flye
But yit me greuys most his nygardye
And wel ye wot that wommen naturally
Desyren vj thinges als wel as I
Thei wold that theyre husbondis shuld be
Hardy . wyse . riche . and fre .
And buxum to his wyfe and fressh in bedde
But by that lord that that for vs bledde
For his honour my self to array
On sunday next me must pay
A hundrith frankis for ellis I am lorn̄
Yet were I leuer I were vnborn̄
Than me were don̄ a disclaun̄dir or a vileny
And yif my husbond myght eke espye
I ne were but lost and therfore I yow preye
Lene me that somme or ellis I most deye
Dan Iohn̄ I sey lene me thise hundrith frankys
Parde I wil not fayle yow my thankis
Yif that yee list do þat I pray
For at a certeyn day I wil yow pay
And do to yow what pleasaun̄ce and seruyce
That I may doo right as yow list deuyse
And but I do god take of me vengeaun̄ce
As foul as hadde gwenilyon̄ of fraun̄ce
This gentil Monk answered in this manere
Now truly myn̄ own̄ lady deere
I haue on yow so gret ruthe
That I yow swere and plight my truthe
That whan your husband is to flaundris fare
I wil delyuere yow out of al this care
And with that he caught hir by the flaunkys
And seid I wil bring yow an hundrith frankys
And hir enbrasid hard and kissid hir ofte
Go now your way qdquod he al stille and softe
And lat vs go to dyner as sone as ye may
For by my chalaun̄dre yt is ner pⁱrime of þᵉ day
Go now and be as trewe as I shal be
Now god for bede ellid fro quoth she
And forth she goth als ioly as a pye
And bad the cokys that thei shuld hye
So that men myght dyne and that anon̄
Vp to hir husbond is this wyfe gon̄
And knokkis at his countyng dore baldly
Quy la . qdquod he ; petir yt am I .
Said she ; how long sir wil ye fast
How long wil yee rekne and cast
Your summez and your bokis and yoᵘur thing
The deuyl haue part of al such reknyng
Yee haue ynough parde of goddis sonde
Come doun̄ to day and lat yoᵘur baggis stonde
Be yee not ashamyd that dan Iohn̄
Shal fast al this day so long gon̄
What lat vs here messe and go we dyne
Whi qdquod this man litil can thou deuyne
The curious besynesse that we haue
For of chapmen so god me saue
And by that lord þat clepid is seynt yue
Skarsly among twenty two . shal thryue
Contynuelly lastyng vnto oure age
We may wel make cheere and good visage
And dryue forth the world as yt may be
And kepe oure estate in pryuete
Til that we be ded or ellis that we play
A pilgrimage or gon̄ out of the way
And therfor haue I gret necessite
Vppon this quaynt world to aduyse me
For euermore we most stand and drede
Of happe and fortune in oure chapman hede
To flaun̄dris I wil go to morwe at day
And come ageyn as sone as euer I may
For which my deer wyfe I the beseke
As be to euery buxum and meke
And for to kepe oure good be curious
And honestly gouerne wel oure hous
Thou hast ynough in euery maner wyse
That to a thrifty husbond may suffice
The lakkith non array ne no vitayle
Of siluer in thi purs thou may not fayle
And with that wurd his count̉redore he shette
And doun̄ he goth no lenger wold he lette
But hastily a messe was ther said
And spedily the tablis were layd
And to the dyner fast thei hem spedde
And richely the chapman the monk fedde
And aftir dyner dan Iohn̄ sobirly
This chapman took on side pryuely
And said thus cosyn yt standith so
That wel I se to bruggis wil yee go
God and seynt augustyne yow spede ⁊and guyde
I pray yow cosyn that yee wysely ryde
Gouernyth yow also of your dyete
Al temperelly and Namely in this hete
Betwix vs two nedith no straunge fare
Fare wel cosyn god sheeld yow fro care
Yif any thing ther be by day or nyght
Yif yt ligge in my power and my myght
That yee wil comaun̄de me in any wyse
Yt shal be doon̄ right as yee wil deuyse
One thing or that yee gon̄ yif yt may be
I wold pray yow to lene me
An hundrith frankis for a wyke or tweye
For certeyns bestis that me must bye
To store with a place of ourys
God help me so I wold yt were youris
I shal not fayle seurly of my day
Not for a hundrith frankis a myle way
But lete this thing be secree I yow pray
For thise bestis this nyght yit most I pay
And fare now wel myn̄ owne cosyn deere
Graund mercy of your cost and of your chere
The noble merchaunt gentilly a non̄
Answerd and seid O cosyn dan Iohn̄
Now sikirly this is a smal request
My gold is youris whan that yow lest
Not only my gold but my chaffare
Take what yee lust god sheeld ye spare
But one thing as yee know yt wel ynough
Of chapmen that þer mony is ther plough
We may make whils that we haue a name
But goldles to be ne is no game
Pay yt ageyn whan yt lyes in your ease
Aftir my myght ful fayn I wold yow please
Thise . C . fraunkis he fecchid forth anon̄
And pryuely he took hem to dan Iohn̄
No wight in al this world wist of this lone
Sauf this merchaund and dan Iohn̄ allone
Thei drynke and speke and rome a while ⁊and play
Til that dan Iohn̄ ridith til his abbay
The morwe cam and forth this m̉erchaıı̄unt rydith
To flaundrisward his apprentice wel hym guydith
Til he come to bruggis merily
Now gos this merchaunt fast and besily
About his nede and byeth and creaunsith
He nouthir pleyeth at the dyce ne daun̄sith
But as merchaunt shortly for to telle
He ladde his lyfe and there I lete hym dwelle
The sonday next dan Iohn̄ þat þe m̉erchauntþat þe m̉erchaunt is gon̄
To seynt denyse is come dan Iohn
With crowne and al fressh and newe shaue .
In al the hous ne is ther man ne knave
Ne no wight ellis but that he was fayn
That my lord dan Iohn̄ was comyn agayn
And shortly to here poynt thei gon

rdg.seg: To seynt denyse is comyn dan Iohn̄
this fayre wyfe accordis with dan Iohn

app.rdg: To seynt denyse is comyn dan Iohn̄
this fayre wyfe accordis with dan Iohn

div.l: And for thise hundrith fraunkis he shuld a nyght
Haue her in his armys bolt vpright
And this accord ꝑperfourmyd was in dede
In myrth al nyght a besy lyfe thei lede
Til yt was day dan Iohn̄ went his way
And bad the meyne far wel and haue good day
For non of hem ne no wight in the toun̄
Hath of dan Iohn̄ right no suspeccyoun̄
But forth he ridis hom to his abbay
Or where hym lust no more of hym I say
This merchaunt whan that endid was the fayre
To seynt denyse he gan to repayre
And with his wyfe he makis feste and chere
And tellis hir that chaffare is so dere
That nedis most he make cheuysaun̄ce
Of som of his frendis or his alliaun̄ce
To pay xx Mˢ. stutys anon̄
For which this merchaunt is to parys gon̄
To borwe of certeyn frendis that he hadde
A certeyn fraunkis and som with hym he ladde
And whan he was comyn vnto that toun̄
For cheerte and gret affeccyoun̄
Vnto dan Iohn̄ he furst gos hym to play
Not for to borwe of hym no monay
But for to wyt and see of his welfare
And for to tellyn hym of his chaffare
As frendis doon̄ whan thei be mette in fere
Dan Iohn̄ hym makis fest and mery cheere
And hym he told ageyn ful specially
How he hadde bought wel and graciously
Thankid be god his merchaundyse
Sauf that he most in al maner wyse
Make a cheuysaun̄ce as for the best
And than he shuld lyuyn in Ioye and rest
Dan Iohn̄ answerd certis I am fayn
That yee in hele are comyn agayn
And that I were riche so haue I blisse
Of xx Mˢ stutis shuld yee not mysse
For yee so kyndly this othir day
Lent me gold ; and as I can or may
I thanke yow by god and by seynt Iame
But neuer the lesse I took vnto oure dame
Your wyfe at home the same money ageyn
Vppon your benke she wot yt wel certeyn
By certeyn tokenys that I can hir telle
Now by your leue I may no lenger duelle
Oure abbot wil out of this toun̄ anon
And in his compeny most I gon̄
Grete wel oure dame my nece swete
And fare wel dere cosyn til we mete
This merchaunt was bothe redy and wyse
Creaunsid he has and payed eke in paryse
To certeyn lumbardys and pays redy in þ̉er hond
The somme of gold and tooke of hem the bond
And hom he goth as mery as a popyn iay
For wel he knew he stood in such aray
The nedis must he wynne in such a viage

And that the Romayns hadde brent Cartage
She was so ful of turment and of Rage
That wilfully in to the fyre she stert
And brent hir self with a stedfast hert
O woful hennys right so cryed yee
As whan Nero brent the Cytee
Of Rome cryed the senatours wyfes
For that their husbondis lost alle their lyfes
Without gilt this Nero has hem slayn
Now wil I turne to my tale agayn
This sely widu and her doughtris two
Herd their hennys cry and make wo
And out at the dore stert thei anon
And saw the fox toward the groue gon̄
And bare vppon his bakke the cokke away
And cryed out and harrow and wel away
A A war the fox and aftir hym thei ran
And eke with staffis many an othir man
Ran Colle oure dogge talbot and garlond
And malkyn with a distaffe in hir hand
Ran cow . and calf and the very hoggis
So ferd were thei for berkyng of þe doggis
And showtyng of the men and woumen eke
Thei Ran so hem thought here hert did breke
Thei yellid as feendis doıı̄un in helle
The doggis cryed as men wold hem quelle
The gees for ferd flowe ouer the trees
Out of the hyfe come the swarme of bees
So hidous was the noyse a benedicite
Certis Iakke strawe and his meynee
Ne made neuer showtis half so shille
Whan that thei wold any flemmyng kille
As thilk day was made vppon the fox
Of brasse thei broughtyn bemys and of box
Of horn and bon̄ in which thei blew ⁊and poupid
And therwithal þei strakid and þei houpid
Yt semed as that heuyn shuld falle
Now good men I pray yow herknyth alle
Lo how fortune turnyth subitanly
The hope and the pryde of enuy
This cokke that lay vppon the foxis bakke
In al his drede vn to the fox he spakke
And seid sir yif I were as yee
Yit shuld I sey als wystly god help me
Turnyth ageyn ye proud cherlis alle
A verrey pestilence mot on yow befalle
Now am I comyn to the wode side
Malgree your hed the cokke shal here abyde
The fox answerd in faith yt shal be don̄
I wil yt sey in feith and þat anoıı̄un
And spak that wurd and subitanly
This cokke brak fro his mouth delyuerly
And whan the fox saw that he was gon
On high vppon a tree anon
Allas quoth hehe Chauntler allas
I haue doon̄ to yow a gret trespas
In as mych as I made yow a ferd
Whan I yow hent and brought vnto this yerd
But sir I did yt in no wykkid entent
Come doun̄ and I shal telle yow what I ment
I shal sey the sooth to yow god help me so
Nay than quoth he I shrewe vs bothe two
And furst I shrewe my self bothe blood ⁊and bonys
Yif þou begyle any ofter þan onys
Thou shalt no more with flaterye
Make me syng and wynke with myn̄ eye
For he that wynkyth whan he shuld see
Almyghty god lat hym neuer the
Nay mary quoth the fox god gyf hym myschaun̄ce
That is so vndiscrete of gouernaun̄ce
Þat ianglith whan he shuld hold his pees
Lo such it is to be Reccheles
And necligent and trust in flaterye
But yee that holdyn this tale a folye
As of a fox and of a cokke and of a henne
Take the moralte good men
For seynt poule seith al that wrytyn is
To oure doctryne yt is wryten ywis
Takith the frute and lat the chaf be stille
Now good god yif yt be thi wille
As seith my lord make vs alle good men
And bryng vs to thyn heuyn̄ blisse amen

Explicit fabula presbiteri ⁊et iam
incipit incipit fabula monialis ⁊etc̉etera
The mynystre and norice vnto vicys
Which men in englissh clepith idilnesse
That porter at the gate is of delices
To eschuen and by hir contrary oppresse
That is to sey in leeful besynesse
Wel ought we to doon̄ al oure entent
Lest that the fend thurgh ydilnes vs hent
For he that with his thousand cordis slye
Contynuelly vs awaytith to beclappe
Whan he may man in ydilnes espye
He can so lightly cacche hym in his trappe
Til that a man he hent right by the lappe
He nys not war the fend hath hym in hande
Wel aught vs wirche and ydilnesse withstande
And though men dreddyn neuer to dye
Yit seen men wel by resoıı̄un doutles
That ydilnesse is rote of slogardrye
Of whiche ther neuer comyth no good encrese
And sithen that slouthe hir holdith in a lees
Only for to slepe and ete and drynkyn
And to deuouryn al that othir swynkyn
And for to putte vs from such ydilnesse
That cause is of so gret confusioun̄
I haue here doıı̄un my feithful besynesse
Aftir the legend in translacyoıı̄un
Right of thi gloryous lyfe and passioıı̄un
Thou with thi garlond wrouȝt of rose ⁊and lilye
The mene I mayde and martyr seynt cecilye
And thou that art flour of virgynes alle
Of whom that bernard lust so wel to wryte
To the at my begynnyng I furst calle
Thou comfort of vs wrecchid do me endyte
Thi maydens deth þᵗat did wynne þurgh hir meryte

div.l: The eternal lyfe and of the fende Victorye
As men may aftir redyn in hir historye
Thou mayden ⁊and modir doughtyr of thi sone
Thou welle of mercy synful soulys cure
In whom that god for bounte ches to wone
Thou humble and high ouer euery creature
Thou nobledist so ferforth oure nature
That no disdeyn had the maker of kynde
His sone in blood and flessh to clothe and wynde
Within the cloystre of thi blisseful sidis
Took mannys shappe the eternal loue and pees
That of the tryne compas lord and guyde is
Whom erthe and see and heuyn doutlees
Ay wurchippyn and thou virgyne wemlees
Bar hym of thi body and duellyd mayden pure
The creatour of euery creature
Assemblid is in the magnificence
With mercy goodnesse and such pytee
That thou that art the sonne of excellence
Not only helpist hem that preyen the
But oftyn tyme of thi benignytee
Ful frely or that men thyn̄ helpe beseche
Thou gost beforn̄ and art oure lyfes leche
Now help thou meke and blisful fayre mayde
Me flemyd wrecche in this desert of galle
Thynke on the womman of cananee þat saide
That whelpis etyn sum of the crommys alle
That from here lordis table been falle
And þough that I vnwurthi son of Eue
Be synful yit accepte my beleue
And for that fayth is ded without werkys
So for to wirche gif me wit and space
That I be quyt from place þat most derk is
O thou that art so fayre and ful of grace
Be myn̄ aduocate in that holy place
There as withoutyn ende is songyn osanne
Thou cristis modir doughtyr dere of anne
And of thi light my soule in prison light
That troublid is by the contagioun
Of my body and also by the wight
Of worldly lust and fals affeccyoun
O . hauen of refute o sauacyoun
Of hem that been in sorwe and in distresse
Now help for to my werk I wil me dresse
Yit pray I yow that redyn that I wryte
For gyf me that I do no diligence
This ilk history subtily to endite
For bothe haue I the wurdis and þe sentence
Of hym that at the seyntis Reuerence
The history wrought and folwyn hir legende
And pray yow that yee wil my werkis amende
Furst wold I yow þᵉ name of seynt C expoun̄
Expoun̄ as men may in hir history see
Yt is to seyn on englissh heuenys lilye
For pure chaastnes of virginite
Or for she whittenesse hadde of honestee
And grene of conscience and of good fame
The swete sauourd lylie was hir name
Or cecelye is to seyn the wey to blynde
For she ensaunple was by good techyng
Or ellis cecilye as I wretyn fynde
Is ioynyd by a maner conioynyng
Of heuyn and lya and here in figuryng
The heuyn is sette for thought of holynesse
And lya for hir lastyng besynesse
Cecilye may eke be seid in maner
Wantyng of blyndenesse for hir gret light
Of sapience and for hir thewis clere
Or ellis lo this maydenys name bright
Of heuyn and leos comyth for which by right
Men myght hir wel the heuyn of poeple calle
Ensaunple of good and wyse werkis alle
For leos poeple in englissh is to seye
And right as men may in the heuyn see
The sonne and mone and sterris euery wey
Right so men gostly in this mayden free
Sawen of feith the magnanymyte
And eke the clernesse hool of sapience
And sundry werkis bright of excellence
And right so as thise philosophris wryte
That heuene is swift and roun̄d and eke brennynḡe
Right so was fayre cecilye the white
Ful swyft and besy and euery in good werkyng
And round and hool in good ꝑperseueryng
And brennyng euer in charyte ful bright
Now haue I yow declarid what she hight
This mayde bright cecilie as hir lyfe seith
Was comyn of Romayns and of noble kynde
And from hir cradil vp fostred in the feith
Of crist and bar his gospel in hir mynde
She neuer cessid as I wretyn fynde
Of here prayer and god to loue and drede
Besechinge hym to ke hir maydenhede
And whan this mayde shuld vnto aman
Yweddid be that was ful yong of age
Which that clepid was Valerian
And day was comyn of hir mariage
She ful deuout and humble in hir corage
Vndir robe of gold that sat ful fayre
Had next hir flessh I clothid in an hayre
And whith that the organs maden melodye
To god allone in hir hert thus song she
O lord my soule and eke my body guye
Vnwemmyd lest that I confoundid be
And for his loue that dyed on tree
Euery secunde and thridde day she did fast
Ay biddyng in hir orisouns ful fast
The nyght came and to bedde most she gon
With hir husbond as oftyn is the manere
And pryuely she seid to hym anon
O swete and wel belouyd spouse deere
Ther is a counsel and yee wold yt here
Whiche that right fayn I wold to yow seye
So that yee swere yee shul yt not bewreye
Valerian gan fast vnto hir swere
That for no caas ne thyng that myght be
He shuld neuer bewreyen here
And at erst to hym sed she
I haue an aungel which that louyth me
That with gret loue where so I walke or slepe
Is redy ay my body for to kepe
And yif that he may felyn out of drede
That yee me touche or loue in vilenye
He right anon wil sle yow with the dede
And in your thought thus shal yee dye
And yif that yee in clene loue me guye
He wil yow loue as me for your clennesse
And shewe to yow his ioye and his brightnesse
This Valerian as god wold
Answerd ageyn yif I shal trust the
Lat me that aungel bright seen and beholde
And yif that he a verry aun̄gel be
Than wil I doon as thou hast preyd me
And yif thou loue an othir man for sothe
Right with this swerd than wil I sle yow bothe
Cecilie answerd right in this wyse
Yif that yow list the aungel shal yee see
So that yee trowe on criste and yow baptise
Goth forth to Via Apia quoth she
That from this toun̄ ne stant but mylys thre
And to the pouer folkis that there duellyn
Sey hem right thus as I shal yow tellyn
Telle hem that I Cecilye yow to hem sent
To shewe yow the good Vrban the olde
For secre nedis and for good entent
And whan that yee seynt Vrban haue beholde
Telle hym the wurdis which þat I yow tolde .
And whan that he hath purgid yow fro synne
Than shal yee see that aungel or we twynne
This Valerian is to the place gon
And right as hym was taught by his lernyng
He fond this holy Vrban anon
Among the seyntys buryellys liggyng
And he anon withoutyn tareyng
Did his message and whan he had yt tolde
Vrban for ioye his handis gan vpholde
The teris from his eyen lete he falle
Almyghty god o ihūIhesu crist quoth he
Sowere of chaastite coun̄seilour of vs alle
The frute of thilk seed of Chaastite
That thou hast sowe in Cecilye take to the
Lo lyke a besy bee without gyle
The seruyth ay thyn̄ owne thral Cecile
For thilk spouse that she took but now
Ful lyke a feers leoun̄ she sendith here
As meke as euer was any lambe to yow
And with that wurd anon ther gan appere
An old man clad in whithe clothis clere
That hadde a book with lettres of gold in hande
And gan before Valerian to stande
Valerian as ded fel doun̄ for drede
Whan he hym saw and he vp hent hym tho
And on his book right thus he gan to rede
O . lord o . feith . o . god without mo .
O . cristendam and fadir of alle also
Abouyn alle and ouer alle euery where
Thise wurdis alle with gold wretyn were
Whan this was rad than seid this old man
Leuys thou this thing or not ; sey ye or nay
I beleue al this thing quoth Valerian
For sother thing than this I dar wel say
Vnder the heuyn no wight thinke may
Tho vanysshid this olde man he nyst where
And pope Vrban hym cristnyd right there
Valerian goth hom and fyndith Cecilie
Within his chambre with aun̄gel stande
This aungel hadde of Rosis and of lylie
Crownys two the whiche he bar in hande
And furst to Cecilie as I vndirstande
He gaf that on and aftir gan he take
That othir to Valerian hir make
With body clene and vnwemmyd thought
Kepith ay wel thise crownys quoth he
From paradise to yow haue I hem brought
Ne neuer more shal thei rotyn be
Ne lese here swete sauour trustith me
Ne neuer wight shal seen hem with his eye
But yif he be chaast and hate vilenye
And thou Valerian for thou so sone
Did assent to good coun̄sel also
Sey what the lust and thou shal haue þi bone
I haue a brothir quoth Valerian tho
That in this world I loue no man so
I pray yow that my brothir may haue grace
To knowe the trouthe as I do in this place
The aungel seid god likith thi Request
And bothe with the palme of Martirdom
Yee shul come vn to his blisseful fest
And with that wurd tyburce his brothir com
And whan he the sauour vndirnam
Whiche that the Rosis and te lilyes cast
Within his hert he gan to wondre fast
And seid I wondre this tyme of the yeer
Fro whens this swete sauour comyth so
Of Rosis and lilies that I smelle heer
For though I hadde hem in my handis two
The sauour myght in me no deppere go
The swete smel that in my hert I fynde
Hath chaungid me al in an othir kynde
Valerian seid two corownys haue we
Snow white and rose red that shyne cleere
Whiche that thyne eyen haue no myght see
And thou smellist hem thurgh my prayere
So shal thou seen hem leef brothir dere
Yif yt be so thou wilt without slouthe
Beleuyn aright and knowyn verray trouthe
Tiburce answerd seys thou this to me
In soothnes or in dreme I herkyn this
In dremys quoth Valerian haue we be
In to this tyme brothir myne ywis .
And now at erst in trouthe oure duellyng is
How wotys thou quoth tiburce in what wyse
Quoth Valerian that shal I the deuyse
The aungel of god hath me þe trouthe taught
Which thou shal see yif that thou wil renye
The ydolis and be clene and ellis naught
And of the myracle of thise corownys tweye
Seynt ambrose in his preface list to seye
Solempnely this noble doctour dere
Commendith yt and seith in this manere
The palme of martyrdom for to receyue
Seynt Cecile fulfillid was of goddis gyfte
The world and eke hir chaun̄bre gan she weyue
Wittenesse of valerian and cecilyes shryfte
To which god of his boun̄te wold shifte
Corownys two of flouris wel smellyng
And made his aungel to hem the corowns bryng
The mayde hath brought men to blys aboue
The world hath wist what yt is wurth certayn
Deuocyon̄ of chastyte to loue
Tho shewid hym cecile al opyn and pleyn
That alle ydolis nys but a thing in vayn
For thei ben dombe and therto thei be deue .
And chargid hym his Idolis for to leue .
Who so that trowith not þis a beste he is
Quoth tiburce than yif þat I shal not lye
And she began kisse his brest þat herd this
And was ful glad he couthe trouthe espye
This day I take the for myn allye
Said this blisseful fayre mayden dere
And aftir that she seid as yee may here
Lo right so as the loue of criste quoth she
Made me thi brothirs wyfe in that wise
Anon for myn̄ allye here take I the
Sithen that thou wilt thyn̄ Idolis despyse
Go with thi brothir now and the baptyse
And make the clene so that þou may beholde
The aun̄gels face of whiche thi brothir tolde
Tiburce answerde and seid brothir dere
Furst telle me whider I shal and to what man
To whom quoth he come forth with good chere
I wil the lede vn to the pope Vrban
Til Vrban brothir myn̄ Valerian
Quoth tho tyburce wil thou me thider lede
Me thynkith that yt were a wondir dede
Ne menys thou not Vrban quoth he tho
That is so oftyn dampnyd to be ded
And wonyth in halkys alwey to and fro
And dar not onys putte forth his hed
Men shuld hym brenne on a fyr so red
Yif he were founden or yif men myȝt hym espye
And we also to bere hym compaignye
And whils we sechyn thilk diuinyte
That is helid in heuyn aboue pryuely
Algate in this world brent shal we be
To whom Cecilie answerd boldly
Men myght dredyn wel and skilfully
This lyfe to lese myn̄ own̄ dere brothir
Yif this were lyfyng only and non othir
But ther is a bettyr lyfe in othir place
That euer shal lastyn ne drede the nought
Whiche goddis sone vs told of his grace
That fadris sone that alle thingis wrought
And that wrought is wit a skilful thought
The gost that from the fadir gan procede .
Hath soulyd hem withoutyn any drede
By wurde and by myracle he goddis sone
Whan he hadde in this world declarid here
That ther was othir lyfe ther men may wone
To whom answerd tyburce o sister dere
Ne seyd thou not right now in this manere
Ther ne was but on god lord in soothfastnesse
And now of thre how may thou bere witnesse
That shal I telle quoth she er that I go
Right as a man hath Sapiences thre
Memory engyne and intellecte also
So in one beyng of diuinyte .
Thre personys may ther right wel be
Tho gan she hym ful besily to preche
Of cristys comyng and of his peynys toche
And many poyntys of his passioun̄
How goddis sone in this world was withhold
To do man kynde pleyn Remyssioun̄
That was y boun̄de in synne and carys cold
Al this thing she vn to tyburce tolde
And aftir this tyburce in good entent
With Valerian to pope Vrban he went
That thankith god and with glad hert ⁊and light
He cristnyd hym and made hym in that place
Perfecte in his leryng goddis knyght
And aftir this tyburce gat such grace
That euery day he saw in tyme and space
The aungel of god ; and euery manere bone
That he god axed yt was sped ful sone
Yt were ful hard by ordre for to seyn
How many wondris IħcIhesu for hem wrought
But at the last to tellyn short and pleyn
The seriauntys of the toun̄ of Rome hem souȝt
And hem before Almache the prefecte brought
Which hem apposid and knew al hir entent
And to the ymage of Iubiter hem sent
And seid who so wil not do sacrifice
Swappe of his hed this is my sentence here
Anon thise martyres that I yow deuyse
One maximꝰus that was an officere
Of the prefectis and his cornyculere
Hem hent and whan he forth þe seyntis ladde
Hym self he wept for pitee þat he hadde
Whan maximꝰus had herd the seyntis lore
He gat hym of the turmentours leue
And ladde hem to his hous without more
And with theire preching or þᵗat yt were eue .
Thei gan from the turmentoure bereue
And from maxime and from his folk echon
The false faith ; and trowid in god allon̄
Ceciy cam whan yt was waxen nyght
With a preest that hem cristnyd alle in fere
And aftirward whan day was waxen light
Cecilie hem seid with a ful stedfast chere
Now cristis owne knyghtis leef and dere
Cast al away the werkis of derknesse
And armyth yow in armure of brightnesse
Yee haue for sooth doon̄ a gret batayle
Your cours is doon̄ your feith yee haue conʆseruyd
Goth to the crowne of lyfe that may not fayl
The rightful Iuge which þat yee haue seruyd
Shal gyue yt yow as yee haue yt deseruyd
And whan this thing was seid as I deuyse
Men ledde hem forth to doon the sacrifise
But whan thei were to the place brought
To telle shortly the conclusioun̄
Thei nold encense ne sacrifice right nought
But on her knees thei settyn hem adoun̄
With humble hert and sad deuocyoun̄
And lostyn bothe here hedis in the place
Here soulys wentyn to the kyng of grace .
This maximꝰus þat saw this thing betyde
With pitous teris told yt anon̄ right
That he here soulis saw to heuyn glide
With aun̄gels ful of clernesse and of light
And with his wurd conuertid many a wight
For which Almachius did hym so to bete
With whippis of leed til he his lyfe gan lete
Cecilie hym took and buried hym a non̄
By tiburce and valerian softly
Within hir burieng place vppon the ston
And aftir this Almachius hastily
Bad his mynystris fecchyn openly
Cecilie so that she myght in his p̉resence
Doon̄ sacrifice and Iubit̉er encence
But thei were conuertid at hir wise lore
And wepid ful sore and gaf ful credence
Vn to hir wurd and cryed more and more
Crist goddis sone without difference
Is verray god this is al oure sentence
That hath so good a seruaunt hym to serue
This with one voice we trowyn þough we sterue
Almachius that herd of this doyng
Bad fecche Cecilie that he myght hir see
And althirfurst lo this was his askyng
What maner womman art thou qdquod he
I am a gentil womman born̄ quoth she
I axe the quoth he þough yt the greue
Of thi Religioun̄ and of thi beleue
Yee haue begıı̄un your questioıı̄un folily
Quoth she that wold two answers conclude
In one demaun̄de yee askid lewdely
Almachius answerd vn to that similitude
Of whens comyth thyne answer so rude
Of whens qdquod she and whan she was fraynyd
Of conscience and of good feith vnfeynyd
Almachius seid ne takis thou non̄ heed
Of my power and she answerd hym this
Your myght qdquod she ful litel is to drede
For euery mortal mannys power ne is
But like a bleddyr ful of wynd ywis
For with a nedlis poynt whan yt is blowe
May al the bost of yt be leid ful lowe
Ful wrongfully begynnys thou qdquod he
And yit in wrong is al thi perseueraun̄ce
Wotis thou not how oure myght princys fre
Haue thus comaun̄did and made ordin̄ace
That euery cristyn wight shal haue pen̄ace
But yif that he his cristendam withseye
And gon al quyte yif he wil yt Reneye
Your prynces aryn as your nobley dooth
Quoth tho Cecilie and with a wood sentence
Yee make vs gilty and that is not sooth
For yee that knowyn wel oure Innocence
For as mych as we don̄ a Reuerence
To crist and for we bere a cristyn name
Yee putte on vs a cryme and eke a blame
But we that knowyn wel that name so
For vertuous we may not withseye
Almachius answerd chese one of thise two
Do sacrifice or cristendam reneye
That thou may now eskapyn by that weye
At which this blisseful fayre mayde
Gan for to laugh and to the Iuge saide
O Iuge confuse in thi nycetee
Wil thou that I renye Innocence
To make me a wikkid wight quoth she
Lo he dissimileth here in audience
He starith and wodith in his aduertence
To whom Almachius seidseid vnsely wrecche
Ne wotis thou not how fer my myght may strecche
Haue not oure myghty princys to me geuyn
